nobby (boat)
Connacht Tribune 16 Feb 1924-5
1 The Cure for Connemara
[…]
Little Potatoes Left A peasant with three arable acres […] is a prince among his fellows.[…] Turf and potatoes are the two prime needs of the poorer type of Connemara peasant. But a great portion of the turf has been sold to Clare in order to bring in a little money, and although Connemara is full of peat lands, many of the bogs have not been opened up owing to lack of proper communciation. […] And, tragedy of tragedies, the potato supply is running short this year. Out at Rossaveel, which has never paraded its poverty, the potato supplies are practically exhausted, and for fire the people are using dried “scraws.” […] And the fishing is mostly done in small boats or nobbies, often in frail curraghs, seldom or never in a properly equipped deep-sea fishing boat.

note.p:
Connacht Tribune 16 Feb 1924-5
3: House Burning
[…]
Dead Goat Precautions. At Galway Quarter Sessions on Tuesday, before the Recorder, Judge Doyle, K.C., Mrs. H. Connelly, Moycullen, sought compensation for the destruction of a dwellinghouse and its contents. […] The door of witness’s sister’s house had been hasped.—“Why was it?” inquired the Recorder.—Witness: We had killed a goat, and the door was hasped in order to prevent the cat getting at the goat (laughter).

list.item:
object of the presence
(coffin) ~
Connacht Tribune 16 Feb 1924-6
1: Mental Hospital
Coffin Placed Inside Asylum Grounds
“A Disgraceful Act.” […] At the meeting of the Committee of Management of the Ballinasloe Mental Hospital on Monday last, an occurrence of a rather sensational character took place.
As the members filed in the main gate to go to the committee rooms, they were astonished to find that during the night or early hours of the morning a coffin had been placed inside the main gates, adjacent to the head attendant’s house. The coffin belonged to the institution and was apparently taken from the stores during the night or early morning and placed there. The members stopped to gaze on the coffin, and notwithstanding exhaustive inquiries as to how it came there, failed to ascertain the object of its presence.
VI.C.3.051(o)-(p)

note.p: Note: Caracciolo. Possibly 1) the princely Italian family of that name, rulers of a number of towns in central and southern Italy; 2) Francesco Caracciolo, Duke of Brienza (1752-99), Neapolitan admiral who served under Nelson and was later hanged by him for treason.

list.item:
I beg your pardon
Connacht Tribune 16 Feb 1924-6
1: Mental Hospital
Coffin Placed Inside Asylum Grounds
“A Disgraceful Act.” […] An Explanation Night attendants Campbell and Hynes came before the meeting to explain why they had not reported an injury to a male patient in their division, who broke his leg […] Dr. Mills said that those two particular attendants had since then absented themselves without leave, and he asked the committee for an order in the matter.
Attendant Hynes: I beg your pardon Dr. Mills. I was here in the hall from 12.30 till 4 o’clock at the two previous meetings when this charge was discussed, expecting to be called in, and I went outside the gate on one occasion to send a wire concerning a daughter of mine who was seriously ill. That was the cause of the absence.
VI.C.3.051(q)

Connacht Tribune 16 Feb 1924-7
4: Pandemonium.
Fight for Road Contracts at Gort […] Division on Co-Option of a Member The boardroom was crowded to inconvenience with a large crowd tendering for roads. […] A heated discussion took place on the question of the time of the tender. Pandemonium gained away in the council chamber […] When the excitement had subsided, Mr. Burke inquired if the tenders were taken in after four o’clock. […] —Contractor: I have witnesses to prove mine was on time.—Second contractor: What do you know about a watch? You never saw one.—First contractor: I went to school as well as you.—Second contractor: You were never there when you were wanted.—This monologue continued ad nauseam.

3: Confraternity of Our Lady of Perpetual Succour During the past few months numerous and repeated requests have been made for admission to the Confraternity of Our Lady of Perpetual Succour. list.item:
I have already shot 14
with this
Ah, sure — tired firing
at us
Freeman’s Journal 16 Feb 1924-4
4: Publican’s Story
Captain Eustace Faces Fresh Charge
[…]
A Loud Knocking John J. Blake, publican, Puckaun, Co. Tipperary, related that on the night of December 15 he was awakened by a loud knocking at the front door, and on demanding who was there from a window, a voice, which he recognised as that of Capt. Eustace, called out—“John, John, for God’s sake come down and give us a drink as my car is after getting broken up.” Witness asked who was with him and he replied: “A lady friend and two gentlemen friends.” […] “Two Strange Men.” He and the lady went out, and the two strange men produced revolvers and placed them on the counter, the low-sized man remarking about his weapon:—“I have already shot 14 with this.” Witness said: “Are you not foolish boys to be carrying these ‘yokes’—what would you do if the military met you?” The man said: “Ah, sure, they are tired firing at us.”
VI.C.3.053(c)

VI.C.3.055(h)

princip.
arch
ang } special case
Note: The sequence beginning at 006(h) derives from an unidentified source based on a commentary—possibly that of Thomas Aquinas—on The Celestial Hierarchy, by the writer known as the Pseudo-Dionysus the Areopagite. The Pseudo-Dionysus is believed to have been a Neoplatonist Syrian monk who flourished around the sixth century. He divided the angels into three hierarchies, each of which contained three orders, forming a total of 9 orders (later also known as ‘choirs’). In the first hierarchy he placed the Seraphim, Cherubim, and Thrones; in the second, he placed the Dominations, Virtues, and Powers; and in the third the Principalities, Archangels, and Angels.

Note: Lutine Bell. The bell of Hms Lutine, which sank in 1799, now hangs at Lloyd’s of London. It is rung whenever there is an important announcement to be made to the underwriters, once if a ship has sunk and twice for good news.

VI.C.3.058(j)

metropolitan chapel >
VI.C.3.058(k)

cave = bonded stores
Freeman’s Journal 16 Feb 1924-8
5: By the Way […] Marlborough St. Vaults Just a hundred years ago the Commissioners of Inland Revenue, who had taken over the vaults of Marlborough street Pro-Cathedral at a yearly rent of 300 guineas, gave up the vaults to Archbishop Murray after seven years’ tenancy of same. In January 1817, these vaults had been rented, and the following entry duly appeared in the Minute Book of the Pro-Cathedral authorities […] ‘Ordered—That the vaults be cleaned out immediately and prepared for the admission of spirits.’ During the seven years that the vaults were used as a sort of bonded stores, the rent accruing brought into the building fund the tidy sum of £2,075. As is well known, the “Metropolitan Chapel” (for so the Pro-Cathedral was designated in 1824) was practically completed in 1824, and it was formally opened on November 14, 1825.
VI.C.3.058(l)

posthouse (High St
Book Lane)
Freeman’s Journal 16 Feb 1924-8
4: By the Way […] The First G.P.O. As the wrecked General Post Office in O’Connell street only came into use in 1818, it is of interest to trace where the first department to deal with postal matters in Dublin was situated. It was established about the middle of the seventeenth cenury, and in 1668 we find it described as a “timber house in High street, with a large garden plot reaching to Back lane, now called the Post House.”
VI.C.3.058(m)

list.item:
supernumerary leg >
VI.C.3.059(e)

none owns >
VI.C.3.059(f)

shod it to boot
Note: These may be based on a story reported repeatedly and quoted from Facts from Gweedore by Lord George Hill. I use Letters on the Condition of the People of Ireland by Thomas Campbell Foster: In an adjacent island, belonging to his estate, three men were concerned in one horse; but the poor brute was rendered useless, as the unfortunate foot of the supernumerary leg remained unshod, none of them being willing to acknowledge its dependency, and accordingly it became quite lame. There were many intestine rows on the subject; at length one of the ‘company’ came to the mainland and called on the magistrate for advice, stating that the animal was quite useless now; that he had not only kept up, decently, his proper hoof, at his own expense, but had shod this fourth foot twice to boot; yet the other two proprietors resolutely refused to shoe more than their own foot (p. 119).
VI.C.3.059(g)

pay carpenter in oats weekly
to make coffin after death
Note: Again from Lord George Hill’s book, quoted by Foster, 121(n): So great was the difficulty of getting even a coffin made, that to secure the services of a carpenter, such as the district afforded, many of the people gave him annually, by way of retaining fee, sheaves of oats, on the express condition of making their coffin when they died!”—Facts from Gweedore, p. 25.
Not transferred.

note.p: Note: St Columcille (c. 521-97). Irish abbot and missionary; founder of Iona in Scotland. He wrote a series of prophecies addressed to St Brendan. heliotherapy
chromopathy
naturopath
naprapath
Note: A list drawn very probably from an article on various forms of treatment for diseases, many of them forms of alternative medicine. Heliotherapy is a treatment using exposure to sunlight; a naturopath is a practioner of naturopathy, which holds that diseases can be cured by natural agencies; a naprapath is one who uses naprapathy. This last is a treatment by manipulation of ailments believed to result from disorders in the connective tissues. Chromopathy may be synonymous with chromotherapy, which treats diseases with coloured lights.
VI.C.3.060(g)-(l)

Note: T. Sturge Moore. British poet (1870-1944). See also VI.B.10.014-16 for Joyce’s Tristan notes, taken from an article by him.

VI.C.3.060(o)-061(a)

note.p: Daedalus 54-5: Bad as our urban conditions often are, there is not a slum in the country which has a third of the infantile death-rate of the royal family in the middle ages. Largely as a result of this, religion has come to lay less and less stress on a good death, and more and more on a good life, and its whole outlook has gradually changed in consequence. Death has receded so far into the background of our normal thoughts that when we came into somewhat close contact with it during the War most of us failed to take it seriously.

MS 47482b-106, MT: since my toils ^+of domestication+^ began famine has receded from the land. | JJA 58:079 | Nov-Dec 1924 | III§3A.*2+
3B.*0+ | FW 539.36-540.02

list.item:
vaccination
Daedalus 55-6: Nowadays the [owner of a large estate] dodders on till about eighty, and is generally incompetent for ten years before his death. His son succeeds him at the age of fifty or so, by which time he may be a fairly competent colonel or stockbroker, but cannot hope to learn the art of managing an estate. In consequence, he either hands it over to an agent who is deprived of initiative and often corrupt, or runs it unscientifically, gets a low return, and ascribes to Bolshevism what he should really lay at the door of vaccination.
VI.C.3.061(b)

(un)desirable parent
Daedalus 57-8: As early as the first decade of the twentieth century we find a conscious attempt at the application of biology to politics in the so-called eugenic movement. A number of earnest persons, having discovered the existence of biology, attempted to apply it in its then very crude condition to the production of a race of super-men, and in certain countries managed to carry a good deal of legislation. They appear to have managed to prevent the transmission of a good deal of syphilis, insanity, and the like, and they certainly succeeded in producing the most violent opposition and hatred amongst the classes whom they somewhat gratuitously regarded as undesirable parents. (There was even a rebellion in Nebraska.)
VI.C.3.061(c)

Q strain of porphyrococcus
escapes into sea, jellies
atlantic, climate changes
fish food, sea red
Daedalus 59-62: As a matter of fact, it was not until 1940 that Selkovski invented the purple alga Porphyrococcus fixator which was to have so great an effect on the world’s history. […]. The food glut was also greatly accentuated when in 1942 the Q strain of Porphyrococcus escaped into the sea and multiplied with enormous rapidity. Indeed, for two months the surface of the tropical Atlantic set to a jelly, with disastrous results to the weather of Europe. When certain of the plankton organisms developed ferments capable of digesting it, the increase of the fish population of the seas was so great as to make fish the universal food that it is now, and to render even England self-supporting in respect of food. It was of course as a result of its invasion by Porphyrococcus that the sea assumed the intense purple colour
VI.C.3.061(d)-(e)

octogenetic
Daedalus 63: It was in 1951 that Dupont and Schwarz produced the first ectogenetic child. As early as 1901 Heape had transferred embryo rabbits from one female to another, in 1925 Daedalus had grown embryonic rats in serum for ten days, but had failed to carry the process to its conclusion, and it was not till 1940 that Clark succeeded with the pig, using Kehlmann’s solution as medium. Dupont and Schwarz obtained a fresh ovary from a woman who was the victim of an aeroplane accident, and kept it living in their medium for five years.
VI.C.3.061(f)

MS 47472-196, TsILA: who […] had been known […] to eat his own length in rainbow trout ^+, as no man of woman born,+^ | JJA 46:070 | Mar 1927 | I.4§1(AB).*4

list.item:
reproduction separate
from sexual love
Daedalus 65-6: As we know, ectogenesis is now universal, and in this country less than 30 per cent. of children are now born of woman. The effect on human psychology and social life of the separation of sexual love and reproduction which was begun in the 19th century and completed in the 20th is by no means wholly satisfactory. The old family life had certainly a good deal to commend it, and although nowadays we bring on lactation in women by injection of placentin as a routine, and thus conserve much of what was best in the former instinctive cycle, we must admit that in certain respects our great grandparents had the advantage of us. On the other hand, it is generally admitted that the effects of selection have more than counterbalanced these evils.
VI.C.3.061(g)

glands ^+cure+^ instead of
flagellation & fasts v sex
alcohol v imagination
prison v sodomy
new vices ?
Daedalus 70-1: We already know, however, that many of our spiritual faculties can be manifested only if certain glands, notably the thyroid and sex-glands, are functioning properly, and that very minute changes in such glands affect the character greatly. As our knowledge of this subject increases we may be able, for example, to control our passions by some more direct method than fasting and flagellation, to stimulate our imagination by some reagent with less after-effects than alcohol, to deal with perverted instincts by physiology rather than prison. Conversely, there will inevitably arise possibilities of new vices similar to but even more profound than those opened up by the pharmacological discoveries of the 19th century.
VI.C.3.061(h)-062(c)

note.p: Note: See reproduction. This has been written in ink in the left margin, next to the previous entry.

list.item:
W grow old suddenly
Daedalus 74: Old age is perhaps harder on women than on men. They live longer, but their life is too often marred by the sudden change which generally overtakes them between forty and fifty, and sometimes leaves them a prey to disease, though it may improve their health. This change seems to be due to a sudden failure of a definite chemical substance produced by the ovary. When we can isolate and synthesize this body we shall be able to prolong a woman’s youth, and allow her to age as gradually as the average man.
VI.C.3.062(d)

sowing dragon’s teeth
Daedalus 79: I suspect that as it becomes clear that at present reason not only has a freer play in science than elsewhere, but can produce as great effects on the world through science as through politics, philosophy, or literature, there will be more Darwins. Such men are interested primarily in truth as such, but they can hardly be quite uninterested in what will happen when they throw down their dragon’s teeth into the world.
VI.C.3.062(e)

250,000 to transcend
hunting pack
— nation
Daedalus 84-5: No doubt there is a fair chance that the possibility of human organization on a planetary scale may be rendered impossible by such a war. If so, mankind will probably have to wait for a couple of thousand years for another opportunity. But to the student of geology such a period is negligible. It took man 250,000 years to transcend the hunting pack. It will not take him so long to transcend the nation.
VI.C.3.062(f)-(h)

science
magnify injustice till it
is intolerable
Daedalus 85-6: I think, then, that the tendency of applied science is to magnify injustices until they become too intolerable to be borne, and the average man whom all the prophets and poets could not move turns at last and extinguishes the evil at its source. Marx’ theory of industrial evolution is a particular example of this tendency, though it does not in the least follow that his somewhat artificial solution of the problem will be adopted.
VI.C.3.062(i)

h fluid ethics
Daedalus 90: There does not seem to be any particular reason why a religion should not arise with an ethic as fluid as Hindu mythology, but it has not yet arisen.
VI.C.3.062(j)

item.seg:
marriage by numbers
subjects of S.J. Paraguay

note.p: Daedalus 40-1: With regard to the application of biology to human life, the average prophet appears to content himself with considerable if rather rudimentary progress in medicine and surgery, some improvements in domestic plants and animals, and possibly the introduction of a little eugenics. The eugenic official, a compound, it would appear, of the policeman, the priest and the procurer, is to hale us off at suitable intervals to the local temple of Venus Genetrix with a partner chosen, one gathers, by something of a glorified medical board. To this prophecy I should reply that it proceeds from a type of mind as lacking in originality as in knowledge of human nature. Marriage “by numbers”, so to speak, was a comparatively novel idea when proposed by Plato 2,300 years ago, but it has already actually been practised in various places, notably among the subject of the Jesuits in Paraguay.

MS 47482b-105v, LPA: It were idle to inquire whether I am the product of group marriage or team work ^+and ^+, surrounded by obscurity,+^ I claim my naturalborn right […]+^ | JJA 58:078 | Nov-Dec 1924 | III§3A.*2
3B.*0 | FW 546.13

domestication of animals *
— plants n
— fungi   Noah
— W Moses >
Note: See also VI.B.6.113(f).
VI.C.3.062(l)-063(a)

steatopygous
Daedalus 42-3: Of the biological inventions of the past, four were made before the dawn of history. I refer to the domestication of animals, the domestication of plants, the domestication of fungi for the production of alcohol, and to a fourth invention, which I believe was of more ultimate and far-reaching importance than any of these, since it altered the path of sexual selection, focussed the attention of man as a lover upon woman’s face and breasts, and changed our idea of beauty from the steatopygous Hottentot to the modern European, from the Venus of Brassempouy to the Venus of Milo. There are certain races which have not yet made this last invention. And in our own day two more have been made, namely bactericide and the artificial control of conception.
VI.C.3.063(b)

note.p: Daedalus 45n: The Hindus have recognized the special and physiological relation of man to the cow by making the latter animal holy. A good Hindu would no more kill a cow than his foster-mother. But the holiness of the cow has unfortunately extended to all its products, and the extensive use of cowdung in Indian religious ceremonies is disgusting to the average European. The latter, however, is insensitive to the equally loathsome injunctions of the Catholic Church with regard to human marriage. It would perhaps be better if both marriage and milking could be secularized.
MS 47472-156, TsILA: his wordwounder ^+, a type ^+born engels+^ who would go on his belly anywhere for milk, music or married women,+^ | JJA 46:031 | 1926-7| I.4§1A.3 | FW 075.22

list.item:
S.D separate statues feet
— quicksilver limbs
Minotaur
flies
Note: Compare the comment in Joyce's early (1899) essay 'Royal Hibernian Academy "Ecce Homo"': 'In the statuary art the first step towards drama was the separation of the feet.' James Joyce, ed. Kevin Barry. Occasional, Critical, and Political Writing (Oxford University Press, 2000), 17.
Daedalus 46-8: I fancy that the sentimental interest attaching to Prometheus has unduly distracted our attention from the far more interesting figure of Daedalus. It is with infinite relief that amidst a welter of heroes armed with gorgon’s heads or protected by Stygian baptisms the student of Greek mythology comes across the first modern man. Beginning as a realistic sculptor (he was the first to produce statues whose feet were separated) it was natural that he should proceed to the construction of an image of Aphrodite whose limbs were activated by quicksilver. After this his interest inevitably turned to biological problems, and it is safe to say that posterity has never equalled his only recorded success in experimental genetics. Had the housing and feeding of the Minotaur been less expensive, it is probable that Daedalus would have anticipated Mendel. But Minos held that a labyrinth and an annual provision of 50 youths and 50 virgins were excessive as an endowment for research, and in order to escape from his ruthless economies, Daedalus was forced to invent the art of flying.
VI.C.3.063(c)

banished Athens murder
of nephew >
Not transferred.

ancestor of Socrates
Daedalus 49: The most monstrous and unnatural action in all human legend was unpunished in this world or the next. Even the death of Icarus must have weighed lightly with a man who had already been banished from Athens for the murder of his nephew. But, if he escaped the vengeance of the gods, he has been exposed to the universal and age-long reprobation of a humanity to whom biological inventions are abhorrent, with one very significant exception. Socrates was proud to claim him as an ancestor.
Not transferred.

glue, saw
Daedalus 48: Save for his valuable invention of glue, little else is known of Daedalus.
Note: According to some legends, Daedalus had a nephew Perdrix, who invented the saw, but who was murdered by Daedalus in a jealous rage.
Not transferred.

note.p: Daedalus 31-2: Perhaps the biggest problems before it in metallurgy are the utilization of low-grade iron ores, and the production of aluminium from clay, which contains up to 24% of that metal. I do not think that even when this is accomplished aluminium will oust iron and steel as they ousted bronze and flint, but it and its alloys will certainly take the second, and possibly the first place as industrial metals.
MS 47472-159, TsILA: Now ^+leaving clashing ash, brawn and muscle and brassmade against ^+to oust+^ earthenborn+^ coming on gradually | JJA 46:035 | Feb 1924 | I.4§1A.3 | FW 084.28-9

list.item:
frescoes increase worker’s
manpower
Daedalus 30: The capitalist’s idea of art in industry at present tends to limit itself to painting green and white stripes on the front of his factories in certain cases. This is a primitive type of decoration, but it has, I think, the root of the matter in it. Before long someone may discover that frescoes inside a factory increase the average efficiency of the worker 1.03% and art will become a commercial proposition once more.
Not transferred.

fires { wood
peat
coal
boots } water (no)
Daedalus 32-3: Desirable substances fall on the whole into two classes. The first are desirable on account of their physical or chemical properties, for example iron, wood, or glass, which we use as a part of systems such as fires, houses, or razors, which procure us certain benefits. The second are desirable on account of their physiological properties. Such substances include foods, drinks, tobacco and drugs. Colours and scents occupy an intermediate position. The value of this second class of substances rests on a quite special relationship to the human organism which depends in the most intimate way on the constitution of the latter, and has not in general been at all fully explained in terms of physics and chemistry. For example, fires can be made of coal or peat instead of wood, but no other chemical substance has the same effect as water or alcohol.
Not transferred.

acid sodium phosphate
for Stosstruppen
purge
Daedalus 34-5: During the war Embden, the professor of physiology in Frankfurt University, discovered that a dose of about 7 grams of acid sodium phosphate increased a man’s capacity for prolonged muscular work by about 20%, and probably aids in prolonged mental work. It can be taken over very lengthy periods. A group of coal-miners took it for nine months on end with very great effects on their output. It has no after-effects like those of alcohol, and one cannot take a serious overdose, as it merely acts as a purgative. (They gave certain Stosstruppen too much!) Thousands of people in Germany take it habitually.
Note: G. Stosstruppen. Storm troops.
Not transferred.

caffeine
nicotine
Daedalus 33-4: So, unless a chemical substance has new physiological properties, its production will serve merely to improve or make possible some appliance whose use lies within the sphere of applied physics. Within historical time two and only two substances of the second class have come into universal use in Europe, namely caffeine and nicotine, which were introduced into this country in the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries.
Not transferred.

food from plants
(2nd hand animals) >>
Not transferred.

plants turn sugar into starch
& cellulose >
MS 47472-38, LMA: ^+growing hoarish under his turban ^+and turning cane sugar into ^+sethulose+^ starch ^+(Tuttut’s cess to him!)+^+^ | JJA 44:133 | Nov-Dec 1926 | I.1§1.*2
2.*2 | FW 029.28

hoofed animals make their
bellies hives of bacteria to
attack cellulose
Daedalus 37-8: The facts about food are rather curious. Everyone knows that food is ultimately produced by plants, though we may get it at second or third hand if we eat animals or their products. But the average plant turns most of its sugar not into starch which is digestible, but into cellulose which is not, but forms its woody skeleton. The hoofed animals have dealt with this problem in their own way, by turning their bellies into vast hives of bacteria that attack cellulose, and on whose by-products they live. We have got to do the same, but outside our bodies.
Not transferred.

note.p: MS 47472-063, TsILA: stood forth ^+dragging the countryside in her train,+^ to crush the slander’s head. | JJA 46:063 | 1925-7 | I.4§2.3 | FW 102.08-9

list.item:
strong farmer
Daedalus 39: Personally I do not regret the probable disappearance of the agricultural labourer in favour of the factory worker, who seems to me a higher type of person from most points of view. Human progress in historical time has been the progress of cities dragging a reluctant countryside in their wake. Synthetic food will substitute the flower-garden and the factory for the dunghill and the slaughterhouse, and make the city at last self-sufficient.
There’s many a strong farmer whose heart would break in two
If he could see the townland that we are riding to.
Not transferred.

key industries >
Not transferred.

key to future (cazzo) >
Note: It. Cazzo. Penis.
Not transferred.

inherit E.
Daedalus 21-2: And as industrial progress continues, an ever larger number—perhaps the majority—of industries will become key-industries. The solution may be entirely different—we may well see a return to feudalism. But the probability is that the problem will be solved. This view may seem optimistic, but it is more likely than the alternative thesis which may be briefly stated as follows: “No human society will ever succeed in producing a stable organization in which the majority of the population is employed otherwise than in agriculture, animal-rearing, hunting or fishing.” It took some thousands of years to produce the stable agricultural society which forms the basis of European life and whose morals we are too apt to regards as eternal truths. It should take a shorter time to evolve a stable industrial society. The people that do so will inherit the earth. In sum, I believe that the progress of science will ultimately make industrial injustice as self-destructive as it is now making international injustice.
Not transferred.

tap wind & sunlight
Daedalus 23: Water-power is not, I think, a probable substitute, on account of its small quantity, seasonal fluctuation, and sporadic distribution. It may perhaps, however, shift the centre of industrial gravity to well-watered mountainous tracts such as the Himalayan foothills, British Columbia, and Armenia. Ultimately we shall have to tap those intermittent but inexhaustible sources of power, the wind and the sunlight.
Not transferred.

h smokes? >
Not transferred.

h HcE chemical
Daedalus 24-6: Personally, I think that four hundred years hence the power question in England may be solved somewhat as follows: The country will be covered with rows of metallic windmills working electric motors which in their turn supply current at a very high voltage to great electric mains. At suitable distances, there will be great power-stations, where during windy weather the surplus power will be used for the electrolytic decomposition of water into oxygen and hydrogen. […] Among its more obvious advantages will be the fact that energy will be as cheap in one part of the country as another, so that industry will be greatly decentralized; and that no smoke or ash will be produced.
Not transferred.

2 Poincaré
Daedalus 17-18: If the quantum hypothesis is generally adopted, even more radical alterations in our thinking will be necessary. But I feel it premature even to suggest their direction in the present unsatisfactory state of quantum mechanics. It may be that, as Poincaré (the other Poincaré) suggested, we shall be forced to conceive of all changes as occurring in a series of clicks, and all space as consisting of discrete points. However this may be, it is safe to say that a better knowledge of radiation will permit us to produce it in a more satisfactory manner than is at present possible
Note: Henri Poincaré (1854-1912). French mathematician, theoretical astronomer and physicist. He was a cousin of Raymond Poincaré (1860-1934), Prime Minister and President of France.
Not transferred.

Columbus
Newton
Einstein } Sign in heavens
Daedalus 13-14: It is perhaps interesting to speculate on the practical consequences of Einstein’s discovery. I do not doubt that he will be believed. A prophet who can give signs in the heavens is always believed. No one ever seriously questioned Newton’s theory after the return of Halley’s comet. Einstein has told us that space, time, and matter are shadows of the fifth dimension, and the heavens have declared his glory. In consequence Kantian idealism will become the basal working hypothesis of the physicist and finally of all educated men, just as materialism did after Newton’s day.
Not transferred.

h accused can now (1920)
give evidence
Daedalus 14-15: The materialism (whether conscious or sub-conscious does not very much matter) of the last few generations has led to various results of practical importance, such as sanitation, Marxian socialism, and the right of an accused person to give evidence on his or her own behalf.
VI.C.3.063(d)

utilitarian
?Daedalus 77-8: I have tried to show why I believe that the biologist is the most romantic figure on earth at the present day. At first sight he seems to be just a poor little scrubby underpaid man, groping blindly amid the mazes of the ultra-microscopic, engaging in bitter and lifelong quarrels over the nephridia of flatworms, waking perhaps one morning to find that someone whose name he has never heard has demolished by a few crucial experiments the work which he had hoped would render him immortal. There is real tragedy in his life, but he knows that he has a responsibility which he dare not disclaim, and he is urged on, apart from all utilitarian considerations, by something or someone which he feels to be higher than himself.
VI.C.3.063(e)

add his quota
Daedalus 40: I should have liked had time allowed to have added my quota to the speculations which have been made with regard to inter-planetary communication. Whether this is possible I can form no conjecture; that it will be attempted I have no doubt whatever.
VI.C.3.063(f)

Poincaré change —
clicks
space discrete points >

light now from
hot bodies radiation ^+95%+^ invisible >
VI.C.3.063(h)-064(a)

lamp waste >
Note: See reproduction for layout for line joining ‘from’ to ‘radiation’.
VI.C.3.064(b)

night, distance, surdity
checks to human progress
Daedalus 17-19: If the quantum hypothesis is generally adopted even more radical alterations in our thinking will be necessary. But I feel it premature even to suggest their direction in the present unsatisfactory state of quantum mechanics. It may be that as Poincaré (the other Poincaré) suggested we shall be forced to conceive of all changes as occurring in a series of clicks, and all space as consisting of discrete points. However this may be it is safe to say that a better knowledge of radiation will permit us to produce it in a more satisfactory manner than is at present possible. Almost all our present sources of light are hot bodies, 95% of whose radiation is invisible. To light a lamp as a source of light is about as wasteful of energy as to burn down one's house to roast one's pork. It is a fairly safe prophecy that in 50 years light will cost about a fiftieth of its present price, and there will be no more night in our cities. The alternation of day and night is a check on the freedom of human activity which must go the way of other spatial and temporal checks.
Note: Surdity. Deafness.

Daedalus 17-19: If the quantum hypothesis is generally adopted even more radical alterations in our thinking will be necessary. But I feel it premature even to suggest their direction in the present unsatisfactory state of quantum mechanics. It may be that as Poincare (the other Poincare) suggested we shall be forced to conceive of all changes as occurring in a series of clicks, and all space as consisting of discrete points. However this may be it is safe to say that a better knowledge of radiation will permit us to produce it in a more satisfactory manner than is at present possible. Almost all our present sources of light are hot bodies, 95% of whose radiation is invisible. To light a lamp as a source of light is about as wasteful of energy as to burn down one’s house to roast one’s pork. It is a fairly safe prophecy that in 50 years light will cost about a fiftieth of its present price, and there will be no more night in our cities. The alternation of day and night is a check on the freedom of human activity which must go the way of other spatial and temporal checks.

nasty blunt club
Irish Statesman 23 Feb 1924-747
2: Correspondence.
The Inland Waterways of Saorstat Eireann. […] As I listened to the debate on the motion that immediate effect shall be given to the Recommendations of the Inland Waterways Commission my spirits sank lower and lower […] it was the manner of the rejection rather than the rejection itself which depressed my spirits, for it was impossible to avoid the reflection that this is the manner in which every constructive proposal will be treated if it involves the least effort to overcome current financial difficulties.[…] The Railway Bill must provide for a Rates Tribunal, and the Waterway Report recommends a single Tribunal for both systems of transport. But, no; the whole Report, all the hopes of the by-traders and merchants on the waterways, were just smashed with a nasty blunt club.

Dear Sir,—The leaderette on the proposed butter legislation in your issue of to-day is quite as misleading as any of your previous articles on that subject. 1-2: Gaelic Plays at the Abbey. Seldom have I enjoyed a heartier bout of uproarious laughter than at the Abbey at the February Gaelic plays, when Pierce Beasley’s Cluiche Cartai was given.[…] There was good team work in this play. Not one actor was weak.[…] Daniel Corkery’s fine play, O’Falvey Mor, was rather poorly played […]. O’Cathain). But they could not save the play.

domestic usage

Irish Statesman 23 Feb 1924-758
2-760
1: The Philosophy of Civilization. By R. H. Towner […] The Philosophy of Civilization, according to R. H. Towner in one of the most interesting books we have ever read, is based on deductions from two premises—(1) That “cold” (i.e., intellectual) women bear children with larger heads than women living under harem and similar systems. (2) That nations who have acquired immunity to alcoholism lead civilization.[…] Mr. Towner must speak for himself.
“If civilization is to continue to rise, it is important that women of augmented mentality remain fruitful. But if they are schooled in a variety of mental exercises outside the home and nursery, their spiritual kinship with childhood will be lost.[…] Rising generations therefore repeat always the same picture—successive generations of mothers of increasing nervous organisation, grand-daughters always more intellectual than their grand-mothers, domestic usages sanctioned by custom and by religion which restrict their outlook upon life[…]”
Note: The author of this review was Oliver Gogarty.

cows milkers
Irish Statesman 23 Feb 1924-762
2: Dairying.
Occasional Notes.[…] Milk in the Tropics.—Dr. R.J. Blackham, late Colonel of the British Army Medical Service, in an address at the world’s Dairy Congress, gave a lurid description of the usual character of the milk supply in the cities of India and of other tropical countries. In India the main source of milk is the buffalo. As meat is little used by the natives of hot countries, the aim of the breeder is to produce cows that will be good milkers, and bulls which will be efficient draft animals.[…] The great disadvantage in milk production is the lack of sappy green food so essential to milk-giving cattle […] As a physician of long tropical experience, Colonel Blackham advocates the use of powdered milk in the tropics. It is, he says, superior to fresh tropical milk in nutritional value, and is more digestible.
VI.C.3.069(j)

scoring butter
with trier
not at churn
Irish Statesman 23 Feb 1924-762
2-763
1: Dairying.
Occasional Notes.[…] Judging the Quality of Butter.—The scoring of butter is a subject of considerable interest to butter-makers. The primary object of scoring is to determine the market value of the article, and it is desirable that all creamery managers should practise the art. But butter should not be judged at the churn, as nearly all samples are palatable when freshly made. Reference samples should be kept for one or two weeks, and then scored. The work should be done in a neat and seemly manner. The hands should be clean, and the trier carefully wiped before it is inserted into the butter.

old cream
poor milk
Irish Statesman 23 Feb 1924-763
1: Dairying.
Occasional Notes.[…] Judging the Quality of Butter.—An American butter buyer reputed to be one of the best judges of butter in the United States, being asked, “What advice would you give a butter-maker anxious to train himself in the art of butter-judging?” replied substantially as follows:—”He should first satisfy himself that he has a good sense of smell and taste.[…] The student should have a starting-point—say a 93 score—with a butter which must be clear in aroma and taste. Having the 93 score one established in his mind, it is easy then to place the 92 because of some minor defect, while in no case can it have a pronounced old cream or poor milk flavour.[…]”

1: The Garden. It may be useful to draw attention to the relatively simple method of growing more fruit by the cordon system.
Note: The vertical bar may represent the cordon system. According to the OED ‘cordon’ means: ‘Hort. A fruit-tree made by pruning to grow as a single stem (usually as an espalier or wall tree).’

VI.C.3.070(i)

trained 45°
Irish Statesman 23 Feb 1924-765
1-2: The Garden. For fruit culture in small gardens the single-stem cordon has several advantages over the orangery bush or pyramid form of tree. The plant is kept pruned to a single main stem furnished from bottom to top with fruit spurs. The particular form is secured by systematically cutting back in the pruning season all lateral shoots to two or three buds. This has the effect of checking shoot formation and of encouraging the storage of reserve food in each of the shortened branches, followed by the development of “fruit buds.” In a well-trained cordon tree fruit will be carried along the whole length of stem from base to current year’s terminal shoot. The trees may be trained upright or sloping at an angle of 45o. […] Cordons come into early bearing as they reach maturity at a younger age than the ordinary form of tree.

Irish Statesman 23 Feb 1924-765
2: The Garden. All varieties of apples are not suitable for Cordons. Among those that are, mention may be made of Beauty of Bath, Bismarck, Bramley’s Seedling, Cox’s Orange Pippin, Newton Wonder, James Grieve and Lane’s Prince Albert. Amongst pears, there are Clapp’s Favourite, Jargonelle, Louise Bonne and Marguerite Marillat. So far as plums are concerned, Victoria seems to be best, but the Czar and Belle de Louvain and several others are used.

2: The Garden. Pears like a light loam, and plums a light soil on gravel. Plums being a stone fruit need lime as a necessary ingredient of the soil.[…] As to the question of aspect, pears and plums may be planted against any wall, but of course a south aspect is the best. VI.C.3.071(g)

no man’s land
= Cyclopia
Note: No man’s land. Generally a piece of unowned land, the term was applied specifically to land north of London, used for executions and, in World War I, to land lying between opposing entrenchments. Here it alludes to Odysseus’ stratagem in Cyclopia, the land of the Cyclops, of representing his name as Outis or ‘No-man’.

Freeman’s Journal 21 Feb 1924-7
6: Provincial News in Brief.[…] Munster […] “Transported” to Thurles.—On Monday all the aged and infirm inmates of Borrisokane and Nenagh Unions were transferred in motor lorries and ambulance to Thurles Workhouse in view of amalgamation. One old lady observed in Nenagh Workhouse as she stepped in the lorry: “May God forgive the men who are transporting us to Thurles, where we will never see the faces of our friends.”
Note: The distance from Nenagh to Thurles is twenty-four miles.

note.p:
Freeman’s Journal 21 Feb 1924-8
5: By the Way […] The Sedan Chair. In view of the discussion at the Corporation meeting the other day on the question of the introduction of taxis for hire on Dublin streets, it is of interest to recall that as late as ninety years ago Sedan chairs were to be seen in the city. Of the last two to be exposed for hire, one was located at the Rotunda, and the other at the corner of Hume street. The first-mentioned did not disappear until 1841.

Kingdom of Kerry
Freeman’s Journal 22 Feb 1924-9
1: Four Courts “Gyrations”
Appalling Bill which Ratepayers Have to Face During the hearing of claims at the Dublin Sessions under the Damage to Property Act, the Recorder referring generally to claims for goods seized, suggested to Mr. Horan, solicitor, who represented the Ministry of Finance, that careful inquiries should be made in all these cases. The ratepayers would have to pay for all this.[…] The Kingdom of Kerry. “Look what the gyrations at the Four Courts cost,” said his Lordship. They cost about a million of money and the unfortunate people of Castleisland will have to pay for them just as the people here will have to pay for what happened in the Kingdom of Kerry, as it is called.

5: By the Way […] The Sedan Chair.[…] What Followed. Subsequent to the disappearance of the Sedan chairs, various schemes of transport came into operation, and amongst them was what was called the “Ringsend Cars,” […] Another type of vehicle which had its wheels inside was much used to take the residents to the “Strawberry Beds” on Sundays. This conveyance caused a wag to observe that as property was scarce in Dublin and human life abundant, they placed the wheels of the cars inside and protected them with the legs of the passengers.

ethnic island
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques xviii-xix: Aucun fait ne justifie les anthropologistes à revendiquer pour leur propre famille ethnique le privilège d’être en tout ou en partie indépendants des influences du milieu. [Nothing justifies anthropologists in claiming for their own ethnic group the privilege of being either wholly or partly free from the influences of their surroundings.]
VI.C.3.073(a)

Kalmuck monk = Ital abbate
anthropoplastic
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques xix: Dans chaque pays, les indigènes arrivent à se distinguer non seulement par l’esprit de corps, mais aussi par le type physique, suivant les professions qu’ils exercent: en quelque pays qu’on soit, on reconnaît le forgeron, le marin, le soldat, l’homme de loi, le prêtre. Telle est la puissance “anthropoplastique” d’un milieu particulier, que le moine catholique des belles régions tempérées de l’Italie et le lama kalmouk, sur les hauts plateaux froids de l’Asie centrale, sembleraient être des frères de race [In each country, the natives come to distinguish themselves not just by their esprit de corps but also by their physical characteristics, according to the professions they practice. No matter what country you might be in, you can recognise the blacksmith, the sailor, the soldier, the lawyer, the priest. Such is the ‘anthropoplastic’ power of a particular profession that a Catholic abbot from the fair, temperate regions in Italy and a kalmouk lama from the high plateaus of Central Asia seem to be brothers of the same race]
VI.C.3.073(b)

Mare Tenebrarum
Atlantic 1400
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques xxi: l’Océan, qui rapproche maintenant toutes les nations et qui les fait une par le commerce et les idées, fut jadis le domaine de la Terreur, le chaos d’où s’élevaient les esprits méchants; cinq siècles ne se sont pas encore écoulés depuis que l’on donnait au redoutable Atlantique le nom de “mer des Ténèbres”. [the ocean, which now brings together all nations and makes them one through commerce and ideas, was once the domain of terror, the chaos from which evil spirits rise. Less than five centuries ago the formidable Atlantic was called the “Sea of Darkness”.]
Note: L. Mare Tenebrarum. Sea of darkness.
VI.C.3.073(c)

tropical & arctic
rivers
extrastorico
Note: It. Extrastorico. Extrahistoric: situated outside the sphere of history.
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques xxiii: tous les fleuves qui parcourent des terres gelées pendant une grande partie de l’année et dont le cours est complètement interrompu par les glaces de l’hiver, tels que le Petchora, l’Obi, le Yénissei, la Léna, le Mackenzie, coulent, pour ainsi dire, en dehors de la zone historique: c’est au domaine de la géographie physique seulement qu’ils appartiennent. De même, dans la zone tropicale, celle où les difficultés de la vie n’ont pas été suffisantes pour aiguiser les énergies de l’homme et où, par conséquent, les populations ne se sont guère élevées au-dessus de l’état de nature, les fleuves n’ont eu qu’un rôle très secondaire dans les annales de l’humanité [all rivers —such as the Pechora, the Obi, the Yenissei, the Lena, the Mackenzie—that run through ground that is frozen for most of the year and whose course is completely interrupted by winter ice, flow, so to speak, outside the sphere of history. They belong to the domain of physical geography alone. Likewise, in the tropical zone, where the difficulties of living were not enough to sharpen men’s energies and where, as a result, the populations have barely evolved beyond a state of nature, rivers have only played a very secondary part in the annals of humanity]
VI.C.3.073(d)

Amazons Rain
9th part of Water
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques xxiii-xxiv: le plus grand courant du monde, la “rivière des Amazones”, qui roule à elle seule dans son lit plus du dixième des eaux pluviales du monde [the largest stream in the world, the “river of the Amazons”, concentrates on its own more than a tenth of the world’s rainwater into its river-bed]

list.item:
canal
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques xxv-xxvi: Sauf pour l’Inde, l’histoire ne remonte pas aux communautés premières qui se formèrent sur les bords des fleuves et qui apprirent à s’entr’aider pour lutter en commun contre les inondations, élever des digues et des contre-digues, creuser des canaux, régulariser le flot d’inondation et la rentrée de l’eau dans son lit. [With the exception of India, history has no trace of the first communities that came into existence on river banks and that learned to help one another in their common struggle against floods by making dikes and counter-dikes, digging canals, and regulating the flow of the flood and the retreat of the water into its bed.]
VI.C.3.073(f)

spiral advance
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques xxvi: La marche en avant n’a point eu lieu d’une manière rectiligne, de groupe en groupe, et c’est par une succession de spirales, de développements partiels et alternatifs, de progrès et de reculs, d’oscillations incessantes, que s’est faite l’histoire de l’humanité. [The advance did not take place in a linear manner from one group to another. The history of humanity has consisted of a succession of spirals, incomplete and alternate developments, forward and backward steps, incessant oscillations.]
VI.C.3.073(g)

note.p: Note: Slang and Dialect. Moke. Donkey.

list.item:
Elie Reclus
Les Primitifs
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques xxvii: Quelle est la pauvre peuplade, si perdue soit-elle dans les forêts et dans les glaces, dont les moeurs et l’existence, décrites avec méthode et sincérité, ne nous force pas à dire: “C’est de nous qu’il s’agit!” J’en appelle aux lecteurs de l’ouvrage écrit par mon frère Elie Reclus, Les Primitifs. [Where is the wretched tribe, however lost in the forests and the frost, whose customs and existence—methodically and sincerely described—do not compel us to say “This is about us!” I appeal to readers of The Primitives, a book by my brother Elie Reclus.]
Note: Elie Reclus. Les Primitifs. Etudes d’ethnologie comparée ... Hyperboréens orientaux et occidentaux, Apaches, Monticoles des Nilgherris, Naïrs, Khones (Paris: G. Chamerot, 1885).
VI.C.3.073(i)

note.p: Note: A horizontal line separates (g) and (h).

Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 1-2: Dégagée de l’idée de progrès, l’histoire ne semble plus qu’un flux et reflux perpétuel de faits bizarres, peu susceptibles d’être subordonnés à une conception générale.[...] Le dévouement, la vertu même, quand par hasard on les rencontre dans les annales du genre humain, y revêtent des formes absurdes - Curtius s’élançant dans le gouffre avec son cheval et ses armes, - ou révoltantes - Manlius décapitant son fils qui, sans autorisation préalable, vient de renverser un ennemi en combat singulier. [Separated from the idea of progress, history seems but a perpetual ebb and flow of bizarre facts, hardly susceptible of being subordinated to a general conception. […] Devotion, even virtue, chanced upon in the annals of humanity, take on forms that are absurd (Curtius bounds into the abyss with his horse and his arms) or repulsive (Manlius decapitates his son who, without prior authorisation, has defeated an enemy in single combat).]

VI.C.3.073(j)

talks with everybody
VI.C.3.074(a)

pragmatic
philosophic } history
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 7: L’histoire pragmatique—celle qui se contente d’enregistrer, dans leur désordre chronologique, les faits et gestes des principales nations du globe—n’est rien moins qu’une monographie du progrès. A une science plus abstraite, à l’histoire philosophique, ou, comme on est convenu de l’appeler, à la philosophie de l’histoire, de livrer le fil d’Ariane nécessaire pour nous conduire à travers le sombre labyrinthe qu’il s’agit d’explorer. [Pragmatic history—the sort which is content simply to record chronologically the facts and deeds of the major nations of the world in all their disorder—is anything but a monograph of progress. It falls to a more abstract science, a philosophical history—or what is commonly called a philosophy of history—to deliver the thread of Ariadne that will lead us through the gloomy labyrinth that is to be explored.]
VI.C.3.074(b)

b zigzag or spiral
corsi ricorsi Vico,
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 8: Il n’y a qu’une seule loi, celle du progrès... Au-dessus de toutes les lois auxquelles les anciens et les modernes ont tenté d’assujettir les mouvements de l’humanité, au-dessus de tous les cycles, de toutes les alternatives, de tous les flux et reflux, de toutes les lignes droites ou brisées, en spirale ou en zigzag, de tous les rythmes, itus reditusque, comme dit Pascal, corsi e ricorsi, comme dit Vico, il n’y a que cette seule loi de progrès qui pour ainsi dire surnage. [There is only one law, progress …Over all the laws to which the ancients and the moderns have attempted to subjugate humanity’s movements, over all the cycles and all the alternatives, all the ebbing and flowing, all the lines, whether straight or broken, in spirals or in zigzags, all the rhythms—itus reditusque, as Pascal said, corsi e recorsi, as Vico said—this single law of progress alone remains afloat, so to speak.]
Note: L. Itus reditusque. Returning movement. It. Corsi e ricorsi. Flow and return.
MS 47482b-78v, LPA: ^+Hail him heathen, heal him holystone
Courser, recourser, changechild, Eld as endall, earthborn,+^ | JJA 58:032 | Dec 1924 | III§3A.*2
3B.*0 | FW 481.02
Note: This entry on 47482b-78v was written before the revised passage on 47482b-79, where it already appears as part of the main text.
VI.C.3.074(c)

h monocellular bion
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 18: On est convenu de donner le nom de bions aux êtres ayant atteint le degré d’individualisation auquel sont parvenus l’homme et les animaux supérieurs. Tout en étant beaucoup plus complexe que celle des êtres d’un ordre inférieur, l’individualité des bions est loin d’être aussi absolue que celle d’une simple cellule. Tandis que les individus monocellulaires se suffisent, non seulement pour vivre, mais aussi pour multiplier, les bions les plus parfaits doivent, pour la conservation de l’espèce, s’unir à d’autres bions de sexe différent. [By common agreement, the name ‘bions’ is given to those beings that have attained the same degree of individualisation as man and the higher animals. The individuality of bions, while much more complex than that of beings of a lower order, is far from being as absolute as that of a single cell. While individual monocellular beings are self-sufficient, not only for living but also for multiplying, the most evolved bions must unite with other bions of a different gender in order to preserve the species.]
VI.C.3.074(d)

list.item:
Jupiter Fluvius
Note: Jupiter Pluvius. Epithet of Jupiter as the giver of rain (mentioned in U 16.41), here combined in a pun with L. Fluvius, river.
VI.C.3.074(l)

Ararat
Solomon’s Throne
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 164: “Le groupe [de monts] le plus fameux, continue l’auteur de la Nouvelle Géographie universelle, est celui auquel on donne spécialement le nom de Thrône de Salomon, Takht-i-Soulaïman... Le sommet du nord, qui est aussi le plus haut (3444 mètres), est une de ces nombreuses cimes sur lesquelles se serait arrêtée l’arche de Noé; une niche pratiquée dans le rocher, près d’un groupe de pierres considéré comme un temple, est le trône où s’asseyait Salomon pour contempler l’immense abîme du monde. [“The most famous group [of mountains], continues the author of the New Universal Geography, is that which is called specifically Solomon’s Throne, Takht-i-Soulaïman… The northern summit, which is also the highest (3,444 metres), is one of those numerous peaks upon which Noah’s Ark is supposed to have halted. A recess made within the rock, near a group of stones considered to be a temple, is the throne where Solomon withdrew to contemplate the immense abyss of the world.]
VI.C.3.074(m)-075(a)

Kohibaba
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 165: A l’ouest de l’Hindou-kouch, et dans la partie la plus élevée du massif, la rivière du Koundouz descend du Koh-i-baba (père des monts), élevé de près de 5000 mètres, pour se jeter dans l’Amou-daria (Oxus) non loin de Balkh, l’ancienne Bactres [To the west of the Hindu Kush, and in the highest part of the mountain range, the Kunduz river, rising to about 5,000 metres, descends from Koh-i-baba (the father of the mountains) before flowing into the Amu Darya (Oxus), not far from Balkh, the ancient name for Bactria]
VI.C.3.075(b)

India & China separated
buddhist propaganda
unite then in
Indochina
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 168: L’Inde et la Chine […] s’ignorent jusqu’aux temps relativement modernes de la propagande bouddhiste. Et quand, enfin, elles franchissent leurs frontières, la rencontre se fait sur un terrain étranger, dans cette région sud-orientale, birmane, siamoise, malaise, annamite, qui, à plusieurs égards, mérite si bien son nom d’Indo-Chine [India and China were unaware of each other until the relatively modern era of Buddhist propaganda. And when finally they went outside their borders, their meeting took place in foreign lands, in the south-eastern region of Burma, Siam, Malaysia, and Vietnam that in many respects well deserves its name—Indo-China]
VI.C.3.075(c)

Fils de Han
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 169: elle a emprunté à l’Inde aryenne sa religion et la majeure partie de son art, et aux Fils de Han ses institutions politiques et son développement littéraire. [it borrowed from Aryan India its religion and the greater part of its art and from the sons of Han its political institutions and its literary growth.]
VI.C.3.075(d)

Chinese
barbarian
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 169: Dans ce massif énorme, l’un des moins explorés du monde, on trouve encore, à quelques pas de civilisations plusieurs fois millénaires, les peuplades les plus rebelles à toute culture: Laotiens et Michmi, Mantzé, Moï, Payu et tant d’autres encore, d’origine et de nature très hétérogènes, mais que les Chinois confondent sous l’épithète méprisante de Si-fan, “Barbares occidentaux”. [In this huge mountain range, one of the least explored in the world, can still be found, not far from civilisations several thousands of years old, those tribes that are most hostile to culture: the Laotians and the Michmi, Mantzé, Moïm, Payu, and still many others. Their origins and character are quite heterogeneous even though the Chinese conflate them under the derisive epithet of Si-Fan, “Western barbarians”.]
MS Cornell-6, PrLMS: getting into their way something scandalous ^+barbarous+^ | JJA 56:104 | Mar 1924 | II.4§2.5
3.7 | FW 394.03
Note: See also 116(n).

Bab-el-Mandeb
(Porte de Perte)
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 170: Le nom de Bab-el Mandeb (porte de perdition, porte de celui qui va à la mort) donné au détroit réunissant la mer Rouge à l’océan Indien, témoigne de l’horreur que ses eaux inspiraient aux Arabes du moyen âge, des mariniers, pourtant, auxquels on ne saurait comparer les descendants des pâtres védiques. [The name Bab-el Mandeb (Gate of Perdition, Gateway For Those Who Go To Their Death) is given to the strait that links the Red Sea with the Indian Ocean. This name bears witness to the horror that these waters inspired in mediaeval Arabs, who were sailors nevertheless, and scarcely to be compared to the descendents of Vedic shepherds.]
VI.C.3.075(e)

Pamir — roof of World
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 174: Les Chinois ne comptent dans l’histoire que depuis la fin du IIIe siècle avant Jésus-Christ, quand leur empire fut absorbé par la royauté des Tsin; alors même ils ne se dirigèrent pas vers l’Hindoustan, dont ils semblaient ne point connaître l’existence, mais vers la Sogdiane et le pays des Ta-Van (Bactriane), par la vallée du Tarim, et en contournant par le nord-est Pamir, le “Toit du Monde”. [The Chinese only figure in history after the end of the third century BC, when their empire was absorbed by the Tsin monarchy. Even then they did not move towards Hindustan, of which they appear to have had no notion whatsoever, but towards Sogdiane and the land of the Ta-Van (Bactrians), through the Tarim valley, and by passing round the North-West side of Pamir, the “Roof of the World”.]
VI.C.3.075(f)

silkwormz
caravan
Note: See reproduction. A vertical stroke follows ‘silkworm’: this may be the opening of an incomplete parenthesis around ‘z’, or it may be a line pointing from (a) to (c).
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 175: A partir des conquêtes d’Ou-ti (186-140 av. J.-C.) et de l’expédition militaire de Tchang-Kien, le commerce de la Chine avec le Ta-Van prit un développement considérable. Des caravanes, dont quelques-unes comptaient plusieurs centaines de voyageurs, se rendaient des bords du Tarim à ceux du Sir-daria. Le docteur Brettschneider croit que les Fils de Han doivent à ce commerce avec les peuples de l’Asie centrale la connaissance de plantes utiles dont quelques-unes encore fort importantes dans leur économie nationale. Les légendes chinoises nous apprennent que le mûrier et le ver à soie de la Chine lui viennent du Turkestan. [From the time of Ou-ti’s conquests (186–140 BC) and Tchang-Kien’s military expedition, Chinese commerce with the Ta-Van increased greatly. Desert convoys, some numbering several hundreds of travellers, made their way from the shores of Tarim to those of Sir-daria. Doctor Brettschneider believes that the Sons of Han owe to this commerce with the peoples of Central Asia their knowledge of useful plants, some of which are still very important to their national economy. Chinese legends tell us that the mulberry-tree and the silk-worm came to China from Turkestan.]
VI.C.3.075(g)

Karakorum (Black Wall)
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 175-6: D’autres puissants rameaux […] partent de l’Hindou-kouch, auquel ils se rattachent par le noeud gigantesque du Kara-koroum (muraille Noire); [Other mighty subordinate mountain chains […] branch off from the Hindu Kush, to which they are linked by the giant knot of Karakorum (the Black Wall);]
VI.C.3.075(h)

Siberia
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 178: Dès que l’un et l’autre [l’Oxus et le Yaxarte] ont perdu leur caractère de torrents de montagne, ils entrent dans le lit de cette autre mer desséchée qui, à l’époque tertiaire, séparait l’Europe de la Sibérie. [As soon as both [the Oxus and the Yaxarte] have lost their character as mountain streams, each enters the bed of this other parched sea that, in the tertiary epoch, separated Europe from Siberia.]
VI.C.3.075(i)

Attila
Tamerlane
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 178: Les cavaliers mongols et turkmènes ont fait plus d’une incursion dans les annales du monde, mais leur brusque apparition sous Attila, Djenghiz-khan, Tamerlan, aux temps obscurs des migrations préhistoriques, aussi bien qu’aux siècles de notre histoire, a toujours présenté le caractère de razzias barbares et de meurtriers cataclysmes. [Mongol and Turkmenistani riders have made more than one incursion into the annals of world history, but their sudden appearance under Attila, Ghenghis Khan and Tamerlane, in the dark ages of prehistoric migrations, as well as in more recent times, has always proved to have the features of barbarous raids and dire disasters.]
VI.C.3.075(j)-076(a)

Wandering river
?Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 181n2: Nos sinologues traduisent aussi par “route” le mot tao qui signifie “ voie”, “méthode”, et, par extension, une grande circonscription administrative, dans ce sens de “canal par lequel le pouvoir central atteint jusqu’aux provinces les plus éloignées”. Mais tao a une signification beaucoup plus large que lou, qui, dans les dictionnaires idéographiques, se classe sous le radical “pied” et exprime une allusion bien plus directe à l’acte de marcher. [Sinologists also translate as “route” the word tao, which means “way”, “method”, and by extension a large administrative district in the sense of “a canal by which the central power reaches all the way to the furthest provinces”. But tao has a wider range of meanings than lou, which in ideographic dictionaries is classed under the root “foot” and expresses a far more direct allusion to the act of walking.]
VI.C.3.076(b)

note.p: Note: Gaffer. An elderly rustic, but in the present context more probably the overseer of a gang of workers. See OED ‘gangster’, which includes the uncommon definition ‘A member of a gang of workmen’, citing an issue of the British Daily Express for 1927.

?Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 182: Pour inscrire son nom dans les annales collectives du genre humain il faut avoir produit quelque chose qui instruise, intéresse ou surprenne la postérité, mais ce n'est certes pas à l'honneur posthume de figurer dans nos manuels d'histoire universelle que visaient, par exemple, les placides constructeurs des Pyramides sur lesquels, dans les sculptures et les peintures égyptiennes, on voit se lever le bâton du contremaître! [In order to write one’s name in the collective archives of humankind, one must have made something that teaches, interests or surprises posterity, but it was certainly not the ambition of the placid builders of the pyramids to have the posthumous honour of figuring in our universal history books when they display in the Egyptian sculptures or paintings the overseer lift his truncheon!]
MS 47474-123, LMA: foostherfather of all of us. ^+Gammer and gaffer we’re all their gangsters.+^ | JJA 48:051 | Mar 1924 | I.8§1.*2 | FW 215.15
Note: This unit appears to have been squeezed in between the surrounding entries.
?Eg. Egyptian.
Not transferred.

list.item:
Congo — classical river
of barbarism
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 184-5: En certaines parties du bassin du Congo, fleuve classique de la barbarie, la plantureuse fertilité du sol a entassé, ici, là, des agglomerations humaines aussi denses que celles des pays les plus civilisés, et pourtant on y pratique encore le cannibalisme. [In certain parts of the basin of the Congo, a river which sets a standard for its barbarism, abundant fertility of the soil has accumulated, here and there, human agglomerations as dense as those found in more civilised countries, and yet cannibalism is still practised there.]
VI.C.3.076(c)

river = synthesis
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 185: Le fleuve, dans tous les pays, se présente à nous comme la synthèse vivante de toutes les conditions complexes du climat, du sol, de la configuration du terrain et de la constitution géologique. [Rivers, in all countries, appear to us as a living synthesis of all the complex conditions of climate, soil, the configuration of the landscape and its geological make-up.]
VI.C.3.076(d)

Nile —
historical value begins
at 2nd cataract
comm 200 km
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 185-6: Le Nil compte, il est vrai, au nombre des géants du monde fluvial, non par l’abondance de l’eau, mais par la longueur du cours [...] mais sa partie historique commence seulement près de Syène, en aval de la deuxième cataracte, et, comme “valeur utile”, il a quelques centaines de kilomètres seulement. [It is true that the Nile ranks among the giants of the world’s rivers, not by its abundance of water but by the length of its course […] but its historically significant part only begins close to Syène, below the second cataract, and for its “utility value” it has only a few hundred kilometers.]
VI.C.3.076(e)-(f)

1st period fluvial
2 — maritime
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 157: I. Temps anciens, période fluviale. [Ancient times, the fluvial period.]
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 187: des civilisations nées sur les bords de ces fleuves acheminés vers le vide glacé de la région arctique, n’auraient pu arriver par voie normale à leur période secondaire, c’est-à-dire à la période maritime. [civilizations born on the banks of rivers that head towards the icy void of the arctic region could barely have attained, in the normal way, their secondary period, that is to say, their maritime period.]
VI.C.3.076(g)

note.p: Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 187: dès que le Hoang-ho avait dépassé la ville de Kaîfoung-fou, il cessait d’être un fleuve et rendait inhabitable le vaste triangle limité au nord par son cours actuel vers le golfe de Pétchili, au sud par le lit qu’il a abandonné il y a une trentaine d’années. [Ever since the Hwang-ho had gone beyond the town of Kaîfoung-fou [?Kai-feng], it ceased to be a river and made inhabitable the vast triangle bounded on the north by its present course towards the gulf of Pe-chih-li and on the south by the river-bed it had left some thirty years earlier.]

[In primitive times, the large streams that are the subject of our study were […] under even less favourable conditions because they had no outlets at all.]
