2.5 | FW 101.30

list.item:
Noah’s ark
VI.C.3.076(h)

Moses cradle
VI.C.3.076(i)

lakeborn
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 191-2: [D’après les géographes du XVIe siècle], les deux plus grands fleuves du monde africain, l’illustre Nil et l’obscur Congo, le Zairé des Portugais, prenaient leur source dans une même mer intérieure, Atché Lounda, censée occuper tout l’espace où se trouvent les puissantes nappes d’eau, Nyassa (Maravi), Bangouelo, Moero Okata, Tanganîka, Kéréoué ou Victoria Nyanza, cette dernière ayant quelque droit à l’appellation de mer, puisqu’elle dépasse en étendue le lac dit mer d’Aral. [[According to 16th Century geographers] the two largest rivers in Africa, the illustrious Nile and the obscure Congo (the Zaïre of the Portugese), took as their source the same inner sea, Atche Lounda, which was supposed to occupy all the area that contains those powerful bodies of water—the Nyasa (Malawi), the Bangweulu, the Moero Okata, the Tanganyika, and the Ukerewe or Victoria Nyanza. The latter has some right to be called a sea because it surpasses in extent the lake called the Sea of Aral.]
VI.C.3.076(j)

sources of Nile
caput Nili
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 192-3: Après avoir lu la description de l’Afrique centrale dans un ouvrage espagnol datant de la première moitié du xviie siècle [...] on peut s’expliquer facilement que le célèbre Bruce, une fois parvenu aux sources du fleuve Bleu ou Bahr-el-Azrak, ait cru et fait croire à quelques savants contemporains avoir définitivement résolu le problème presque cent fois séculaire du Caput Nili, problème qui, depuis la plus haute antiquité, a passionné tant d’hommes éminents et coûté la vie à tant d’explorateurs. [After having read the description of Central Africa in a Spanish book from the first half of the 17th Century […] it is easy to explain how the famous Bruce, once he had reached the source of the Blue River or Bahr-el-Azrak, had believed and convinced a number of contemporary scholars that he had resolved for once and for all the many centuries-old problem of the Caput Nili, a problem that since the most ancient antiquity has impassioned so many eminent men and cost the lives of so many explorers.]
Note: L. Caput Nili. Source of the Nile.
VI.C.3.076(k)-077(a)

mouesi
= lune ou
voleur (qui travaille
à l’aide de la lune)
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 193: Ou-nyamouézi, le nom de la contrée au sud du lac Victoria, est composé de trois mots bantou: ou (pays), nya (particule de relation), mouzi (lune). [Ou-nyamouézi, the name of the region to the south of Lake Victoria, is composed of three Bantu words: ou (land), nya (linking element), and mouzi (moon).]
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 193n3: Burton affirme cependant que le “Pays de la Lune”, se traduirait en bantou par Ou-mouézi, et que la particule de relation nya serait de trop. Mais mouézi signifie aussi “voleur” (probablement celui qui travaille au clair de la lune, de nuit et non de jour). [Burton affirms that the “Land of the Moon” is translated into Bantu as Ou-mouézi and that the linking element nya is superfluous. But mouézi also means “thief” (probably in the sense of one who works by moonlight).]
VI.C.3.077(b)

only the Pharaoh
or chief priest knows
‘Head of Nile’
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 194-5: En regard des idées à peu près vraies de Ptolémée, voyons quel était, aux derniers temps de l’empire pharaonique, le résumé de la sagesse égyptienne au sujet du grand mystère de la “Tête du Nil”. D’après Hérodote, le voile n’était levé que pour un seul homme, le scribe sacré du temple de la déesse Neit (Athéné, Minerve) à Saïs. [In the context of Ptolemy’s fairly accurate ideas, let us see what was the sum of Egyptian knowledge at the end of the Pharaonic empire, about the mystery of the “Head of the Nile”. According to Herodotus, the veil was lifted for one man only, the sacred scribe of the Temple of the goddess Neit (Athena, Minerva) in Saïs.]
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 195n1: Sans doute une innovation des temps saïtes: anciennement le pharaon seul passait pour connaître le mystère du Nil, et c’était l’un de ses principaux titres à la vénération du peuple. [No doubt an innovation of Saïsian times: previously only the Pharaoh was supposed to know the mystery of the Nile and this was one of his chief claims to the veneration of his people.]
VI.C.3.077(c)

note.p: Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 196: Il nous semble plus extraordinaire que cette origine fût regardée comme un mystère redoutable, puisque le plus infime des pêcheurs et des bateliers, ces corporations abjectes de l’Egypte ancienne, pouvait de son oeil sacrilège profaner la sainteté de ces lieux. [It seems extraordinary to us that this origin was seen as a formidable mystery since the lowliest of fishermen and boatmen, these despised guilds of Ancient Egypt, could profane the sanctity of these places with their sacrilegious looks.]

MS 47482b-106, MT: had she left her ^+crocus+^ bed at the suggestion of some infamous fishermen | JJA 58:079 | Dec 1924 | III§3A.*2+
3B.*0+ | FW 546.36

list.item:
all Caesars appoint
Nile commissions
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 196: Néron, passionné comme tous les césars des premiers temps de l’Empire pour la question de la “Tête du Nil” envoya deux centurions à la recherche des véritables sources du grand fleuve [Nero, impassioned like all Caesars at the beginning of the Empire about the question of the “Head of the Nile”, sent two centurions to search for the true sources of this great river]
VI.C.3.077(d)

embarras : floating grasses
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 196: ils avaient réussi à le remonter plus haut que son confluent avec la rivière des Arabes, plus loin que n’importe lequel de nos voyageurs européens d’il y a cinquante ans, lorsqu’ils furent arrêtés par les sedd ou seudd, ces amas d’herbes flottantes auxquels on peut appliquer le nom d’ “embarras”, dans le sens qu’attribuent à ce mot les créoles de la Louisiane. [they had managed to go upstream, beyond its confluence with the stream of the Arabs, and further than any of our European travellers of the past fifty years, until they were stopped by the sedd or seudd, this accumulation of floating grasses that we might call “embarras”, in the sense this word has among the Creoles of Louisiana.]
Note: Creole. Embarras. Places where the navigation of rivers is rendered difficult by the accumulation of driftwood (from the Fr. Embarras. Obstacle).
VI.C.3.077(e)

floating isles
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 202: des îles boisées et des îlots, s’élevant hors de l’eau comme des bouquets de papyrus, bordent les rives; souvent, surtout au commencement des crues, on voit des îles flottantes passer au fil du courant. [wooded islands and islets, rising out of the water like bundles of papyrus, flank the shores. Often, especially when the water begins to swell, one sees these floating isles follow the stream.]
VI.C.3.077(f)

Nile (false) beds
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 202-3: C’est à la formation rapide des îles d’herbes que le Nil doit d’avoir été fréquemment bloqué dans cette partie de son cours, et forcé de se creuser de nouveaux lits. Dans les plaines qui s’étendent à l’ouest du Nil actuel, on remarque, en beaucoup d’endroits, les restes d’anciens courants, “fausses rivières” qui furent autrefois le Nil... [The Nile must often have become blocked in this part of its stream by the rapid formation of these grassy islands, and been forced to hollow out new beds. In the plains that stretch out to the west of the present Nile, may be seen in many places the remains of former streams, “pseudo-rivers” that had once been the Nile…]
VI.C.3.077(g)

note.p: Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 204: Terre qui se forme, la couche de débris finit par se consolider; elle se recouvre de papyrus, même de végétation arborescente, et des forêts croissent au-dessus d’un fleuve caché, qui continue lentement son cours dans ses profondeurs. [Land in the making, the layer of debris ends by becoming solid; it is covered over by papyrus, even by arborescent vegetation, and forests grow over a hidden river that slowly pursues its course deep down.]
MS 47474-129, TsTMA: ^+She thought she’d sink under the ground with shame!+^ | JJA 48:063 | Jun 1924 | I.8§1.3 | FW 202.32-3

list.item:
isles form — raft >
VI.C.3.078(a)

tribes fish in soil
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 204: Le Joug des Rivières est la partie du fleuve où les végétaux barrent le plus souvent le passage; les îles flottantes qu’apportent les courants et les bayous latéraux, s’arrêtent aux brusques tournants et s’étendent, de rive à rive, en un radeau mobile.[…] Des familles nombreuses de la tribu des Nouêr installent leurs campements sur le tapis d’herbes flottantes, se nourrissant uniquement des poissons qu’il pêchent en perçant le sol et des graines d’espèces diverses de nymphéacées. [The Yoke of the Streams is the part of the river where vegetation most frequently obstructs the flow. The floating isles, carried along by the currents and lateral bayous, stop with the sudden bends and stretch out from shore to shore like a moving raft.[…] Large families from the Nouêr tribe raise their encampments on the carpet of the floating grasses, nourishing themselves solely on the fish they catch by piercing through the soil and on the seeds of the diverse species of water lilies.]
VI.C.3.078(b)

Gessi expedition
corpsefed
rescued by Marno
(austr)
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 205: en 1880, l’Italien Gessi, à la tête de 500 soldats du khédive et de nombreux esclaves noirs, se débattit misérablement pendant trois mois au milieu de ces obstacles. Plus de la moitié des hommes fut emportée par la famine ou succomba aux miasmes délétères de ces amas énormes de végétaux en décomposition: les survivants, réduits à se nourrir de cadavres, durent leur salut à l’expédition amenée à leur secours par le célèbre explorateur et chasseur autrichien, Marno. [in 1880, the Italian Gessi, leading 500 of the Khedive’s soldiers and many black slaves, miserably floundered for three months amidst these obstacles. More than half his men were carried off by hunger or succumbed to the noxious miasmas caused by these enormous heaps of decomposing vegetation. The survivors, reduced to subsisting on corpses, owed their salvation to the rescue expedition led by Marno, the famous Austrian explorer and hunter.]
VI.C.3.078(c)

White Nile
Blue
?Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 206: Le Nil, perdu au milieu des herbages, semble désormais impropre à toute navigation, mais la rivière des Gazelles, aux multiples affluents, vient lui verser les eaux recueillies entre le pays des Niam-Niam anthropophages et la contrée des Wadj; son rapide courant a bientôt balayé les “embarras”, et le grand fleuve, enrichi des apports de la région sud-abyssinienne que lui versent le Sobat et le Bahr-el-Azrek ou fleuve Bleu, devient accessible aux navires. Entre Khartoum et la jonction du Nil blanc et de l’Atbara, le passage se trouve intercepté de nouveau par la sixième cataracte [The Nile, lost amidst grass-lands, from now on seems unsuitable for all navigation, but the Gazelle Stream, with many tributaries, discharges into it the waters gathered between the land of the cannibalistic Niam-Niam and the Wadj region. Its swift current soon clears away the “embarras” [obstacles] and the great river—enriched by alluvial deposits from the South Abyssinian region that the Sobat and the Bahr-ep-Azrek or Blue River pour into it—becomes accessible to ships. Between Khartoum and the junction of the White Nile with the Atbara, the passage is again cut off by the sixth cataract]
VI.C.3.078(d)

river changes colour
but for tributary wd end
?Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 208n1: Russegger ne se trompait pas de tout point quand il prenait le Sobat pour le vrai Nil Blanc: en premier lieu, c’est après avoir reçu cette rivière, que le fleuve principal prend la couleur crayeuse qui lui a valu son nom; ensuite, dans ses périodes de crue, le Sobat charrie plus d’eau que le Nil: par contre, il a ses baisses, pendant lesquelles il ne conserve pas assez de fond pour porter des embarcations, même très modestes. Le négrier maltais Andrea de Bono, fut retenu plusieurs fois prisonnier du Sobat par un de ces brusques retraits des eaux. [Russegger was in no way mistaken when he took the Sobat to be the true White Nile. Firstly, it is after receiving this stream, that the main river takes on the chalky colour to which it gives its name. Further, in flood season, the Sobat carries more water than the Nile. On the other hand, it has its subsidances during which it does not maintain enough depth to carry even the smallest boats. The Maltese slave-trader Andrea de Bono, was held prisoner by the Sobat several times by one of these abrupt withdrawals of water.]
VI.C.3.078(e)

item.seg:
Upper Nile made Lower Nile
Lower Nile made history

note.p: ?Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 207-8: Mais à un certain point de vue, et en dépit des brillantes découvertes des explorateurs modernes, la révélation de la Minerve de Sais sur Krophi et Mophi restera éternellement vraie: c'est près d'Éléphantine que se trouve, en effet, l'abîme mystérieux, le gouffre idéal qui partage le fleuve géant de l'Afrique en deux sections de longueur fort inégale, et très distinctes pour la sociologie et l'histoire : en aval, le Nil des inondations qui a créé l’Egypte, et, par conséquent, la commune civilisation occidentale; en amont, le tronçon énorme qui, d’année en année et depuis tant de siècles, n’a créé et ne crée que le Nil inférieur et ses inondations. [But from a certain perspective, and despite the brilliant discoveries of modern explorers, the revelation of the Minverva of Sais on Krophi and Mophi remains eternally true: it is close to Elephantine that one finds the mysterious abyss, the ideal border that cuts the giant river from Africa into two sections of unequal length, and of very different sociological and historical import: downstream, the flooding Nile that created Egypt and, as a result, our shared western civilization; upstream, the enormous portion that, year after year for so many centuries, created and still creates only the lower Nile and its floods.]
MS 47474-132, TsILA: she washed herself with bogwater and mudsoap ^+, upper and lower,+^ from her crown to her sole. | JJA 48:065 | Jun 1924 | I.8§1.3 | FW 206.31

?Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 209: Le mur oriental ou arabique le serre cependant de plus près, pour qu’à la fin de sa longue et glorieuse carrière, le Nil ne détourne pas ses flots vers la mer Rouge, ce qui eût été fatal pour l’Égypte et pour l’histoire du monde entier. [The Oriental or Arabic wall presses it still closer so that at the end of its long and glorious career the Nile does not divert its course towards the Red Sea, something which would have been fatal for Egypt and for the history of the whole world.]

MS 47482b-106, LMA: had my faithful wife ^+Fulvia+^ turned back on her ways ^+in search of brunette men+^ | JJA 58:079 | Nov-Dec 1924 | III§3A.*2+

list.item:
green Nile
(in fermentation)
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 213: On sait seulement qu’avant de déposer ses alluvions précieuses sur la terre inondée, Hapi le bienfaisant les soumet à un triage préalable: par suite de leur moindre pesanteur spécifique, les débris organiques des sedd surnagent dès l’abord et déterminent le phénomène du Nil vert, la phase première de la crue. L’eau du grand fleuve, qui d’ordinaire est très bonne et très douce, est alors empoisonnée et on se garde de la boire. [We know only that before depositing its precious alluvium onto the flooded earth, the beneficent Hapi subjects them to a preliminary sorting. On account of their lower specific gravity, the organic debris of the sedd float at the outset and constitute the phenomenon of the Green Nile, the first stage of the flood. The water of the great river, which is normally quite drinkable and fresh, is poisoned at this time and one must avoid drinking it.]
VI.C.3.078(g)

red Nile
(deposits black mud)
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 214: Tout danger a disparu à la phase secondaire, celle du Nil rouge, bien qu’il ait alors une apparence des plus étranges et semble rouler du sang. Si on en laisse reposer l’eau dans un verre, on voit une sorte de boue noire se précipiter vers le fond, mais la partie supérieure reste rouge et opaque, et le mélange n’a ni goût, ni propriété désagréable. [All danger has disappeared in the second stage, that of the Red Nile, when it has the strangest appearance and seems to stream bloodily along. If one lets some water rest in a glass, one sees a kind of black mud precipitate towards the bottom, but most of it remains red and opaque and the mixture has neither taste nor any disagreeable property.]
VI.C.3.078(h)

Nourisher of world
benefactor
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 214-15: Mais, tout d’abord, une question s’impose: ces inondations périodiques et fécondantes du Nil sont-elles un bienfait indiscutable […] Depuis Hérodote jusqu’à nos jours, on a tant insisté sur les bienfaits exceptionnels des débordements du Nil, que la question pourrait sembler oiseuse. Les surnoms honorifiques et caressants que les laboureurs indigènes ont toujours donnés au grand fleuve: sous les pharaons, Tsaf-en-Ta (Nourrisseur du Monde), et, sous les oppresseurs actuels du fellah, Abou-el-Baraka (Père de la Bénédiction), confirmeraient cette idée [But to begin with, one question demands our attention: are these periodic and fecundating floodings of the Nile an indisputable benefit […] From Herodotus’s time to our own, so much has been made of the exceptional benefits conferred by the Nile’s flooding that the question might seem superfluous. The honorifics and terms of endearment that the native tillers have always given to this great river tend to confirm this idea: under the pharaohs, Tsaf-en-Ta (Nourisher of the World) and, under the current oppressors of the Fellah, Abou-el-Baraka (Father of Benediction)]

Note: According to folklore, gypsies were supposed to be from Egypt.
VI.C.3.079(g)

Pharaoh
2 jobs
prayer to self
pyramids
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 230: D’après les monuments de l’ancien empire, le rôle d’un pharaon de cette époque se réduisait: 1° à s’adresser un culte à lui-même, 2° à faire construire des pyramides, c’est-à-dire à gaspiller les vies de ses adorateurs par dizaines de mille, pour ériger les monstruosités gigantesques qui font l’étonnement des siècles. [According to the monuments of the ancient empire, the role of a pharaoh of this time was confined to: 1) directing a cult to himself and 2) building pyramids, that is to say squandering the lives of his worshippers in tens of thousands in order to erect the gigantic monstrosities that have been a wonder for centuries.]

note.p: Note: See Giraldus Cambrensis Topography of Ireland 117-18: Five chiefs, all brothers [...] arrived in Ireland, and, finding it uninhabited, divided the country into five equal parts, of which each took one. Their bounds meet at a stone standing near the castle of Kyllari, in Meath, which stone is called the navel of Ireland, because it stands in the middle of the country. Hence that part of Ireland is called Meath (Media), because it lies in the middle of the island; but it formed neither of the five famous provinces whose names I have before mentioned. For, when the aforesaid five brothers, Gandius, Genandius, Sagandius, Rutherrargus, and Slanius, had divided the island into five parts, each of these parts had a small portion of Meath, abutting on the stone just mentioned [...] In process of time [...] Slanius alone obtained the monarchy of the whole of Ireland.[...] He first reunited the five portions of Meath, and forming them into one province, appropriating the whole of Meath to the royal table.

note.p: Note: Old Patrick. This figure, a near-contemporary Doppelgänger of St Patrick, appears in Irish Annals under various synonyms, L. Senex Patricius and Ir. Sen Phátric. Modern scholarship represents him as a phantom figure, owing his existence to an attempt to reconcile inconsistencies in dating. He has been seen as a composite of St Patrick and Palladius. See VI.B.14.134(g).

note.p: The History of Ireland 80: From the beginning of his reign he had contemplated the conquest of Ireland. One must clearly understand that by the standard of his age a king might not only justifiably but laudably undertake conquest wherever he found an opening; and in many cases he could secure the highest ecclesiastical sanction. In the case of Ireland, Henry had secured it long years before he acted. From the Pope Adrian IV ., an Englishman, he got the Bull known from its opening word as “ Lauda biliter ,” “Laudably and profitably hath your excellence conceived the design.”

The History of Ireland 70: On Murtough's death a fresh attempt was made to bring in Malachy; but another kinsman, Niall, succeeded to Murtough's claim and held the right for some years till at last Niall was driven out, but carried off with him the Book of Armagh--which was then believed to be St Patrick's own copy of the Testament--and the Bachal Iosa or crozier , which was also a main jewel of the coarb in Armagh.
VI.C.3.087(k)

eastern
subjects
Note: These two entries have been written in the left margin.
The History of Ireland 15: Half a century after Cormac's death, three princes of the Royal house, the Collas, undertook conquest in the north. They captured Emania and destroyed it, about 330 a.d.; they won a territory in the centre of Ulster comprising what is now the counties of Armagh and Monaghan, with part of Tyrone and Derry. This was termed henceforth the kingdom of Oriel, that is Oirghialla, “the eastern subjects ,” so called because the home of this monarchy still lay west in Connaught.
VI.C.3.087(h)

Longford
Leitrim)
The History of Ireland 66-7: Connaught was a growing power under the O’Conors and what had [66] formerly been the sub-kingdom of
Brefny
, comprising roughly
Cavan, Longford, and Leitrim
, now came almost into the first rank, while Meath had fallen decidedly into the second.
VI.C.03.087(l)

I no part in crusades
unchivalrous
The History of Ireland 74-5: Another fact should be borne in mind to illustrate Ireland's position in Christendom. The first Crusade began in 1097, two years after St Malachy's birth; the second in 1147, the year before his death. They were an international effort of European Christendom, to which recruits flocked from all countries on the Continent, and from England, now Norman and continental in its rule; but none came from Ireland. That stamps Ireland's remoteness from continental Christendom. Also, in the period of crusades, the institution of chivalry took its shape. The profession of arms in so far as it was identified with knighthood came under the special protection of the Christian Church. Continental Europe, to which the Norman conquest had annexed England, was in truth at this period remarkably homogeneous. The organisations of the Church, the institutions of feudalism, the rules of chivalry, were the same in France, Spain, Italy, Germany, or rather in all the petty States out of which these nations grew. Literature in all of them had a common character; but the Chanson de Roland has no kinship with the story of Cuchulain or the Ossianic tales; they belong to a different racial tradition. But the essential feature of the difference lay in all the ideas connected with knightood. To continental Europe knighthood was international, a warrior caste of all Christendom in which every member of the caste was bound to recognise obligations in honour, courtesy, and fairplay to another. But a consequence was that to this caste all outside its ranks seemed barbarous; its class-spirit, chivalrous perhaps to its own order, allowed the knight to treat all below or beyond his class with scorn and cruelty, and without good faith. Ireland's fighters, outside the Crusades, were outside the pale [74] of chivalry.
VI.C.3.088(a)-(b)

Clan Colman
The History of Ireland 42: What really happened was that after the reign of Dermod, with whom Columcille quarrelled, his territory, the kingdom of Meath, was divided between two sons, Colman and Hugh Slane. Colman got the western portion; Hugh got Bregia--that is, the present Meath, with parts of County Dublin and Louth. Of the two lines, Clan Colman were the stronger and provided most of the High Kings; but Tara was in Bregia. Thus the Hy Neill dynasty was broken up at its original seat of power; and a High King from
Clan Colman was always likely to have his power challenged in Tara itself.
VI.C.3.088(c)

founder of abbey

(
Deas-Mu mhan, South Munster ); and its right of sovereignty was challenged by a rival dynasty, the Dal-cassian line, They held the smaller and poorer province of Thomond ( Tuath-Mumhan , North Munster), which was only County Clare, with part of Limerick and Tipperary; but they were a hardy race.

note.p: The History of Ireland 56: About 930 a new fleet fixed its head-quarters on an island in the Shannon at the top of the tideway, founding there the city of Limerick. This horde was dreadfully active, and Munster suffered even worse than the rest of Ireland. According to the “Wars of the Gael and Gall,” they levied rent upon every king and chieftain, and in each territory put a Danish overlord and a steward in every village and a soldier in every house, so that none of the men of Erinn had power to give even the milk of his cow, nor as much as the clutch of eggs of one hen, in succour or in kindness to an aged man or a friend, but must preserve them for the foreign steward or bailiff or soldier.

The History of Ireland 77: In the next year there was a meeting in Meath between Turlough O'Conor, Murtough O'Loughlin, King of all Ulster, and Dermot MacMurrough. These three were the outstanding powers in Ireland. They arranged to divide Meath between two claimants; just as earlier in the same year Turlough had once again divided Munster between the
O'Briens of Thomond and the MacCarthys of Desmond. They made a further territorial arrangement, taking away what is now County Longford from Tiernan O'Rourke, Prince of Brefny. On the expedition which enforced this surrender Dermot MacMurrough carried off with him, to Ferns, Dervorguilla, O'Rourke's wife, a willing captive.
It is said that Dermot's main motive was to put an insult on O'Rourke. Dervorguilla was at this time forty-four , Dermot forty-two , and O'Rourke sixty . The lady was brought back next year to the care of the “men of Meath,” whose king was her brother, a MacLoughlin. Some say she entered a convent, some that she went back to O'Rourke. At all events she was one of the benefactresses of the new monastery of Mellifont; and she caused to be built also a very beautiful chapel in a nunnery which she founded at Clonmacnoise;

The History of Ireland 81: Far the best account of the Norman Conquest is given in a Norman-French poem written probably at Waterford by one who derived his knowledge from Morice Regan, an Irishman, Dermot's
Latimer —that is, secretary employed to put the Irish king's correspondence or speech into Latin, which was then the international language.

The History of Ireland 84: In the spring of 1170 Dermot decided to reassert his claim to be overlord of Dublin. He had been so recognised, and the song of Dermot names “MacTorkil,” King of Dublin, as among the traitors who deserted him when he was driven out. Marching north, with Maurice FitzGerald in command of the English, he entered the Daneland , and the citizens, to save their possessions, gave hostages for submission.

Note: Lat. Amnis Lifnius. This is presumably a Liffey-biased variant of the Amnis Libnius, the standard Latin form of the river found on Ptolemy’s map of Ireland. Ptolemy’s river is on the west coast, but at least one historian (D’Alton, in his History of the Co. Dublin) has identified it with the Liffey itself, as seemingly has FW at 250.20, 540.07. Freeman’s Journal 25 Feb 1924-5
1: Fight for Dublin Seats
President’s Appeal for Co-operation to Rebuild the Nation
Brisk Retorts to Hecklers […] Support for National Candidates President Cosgrave addressed a very large meeting in College street, Dublin, yesterday in support of the candidature of Mr. James O’Mara for the South City vacancy.[…] As usual there was a small disorderly element […] One young woman, sporting a red hat and holding a note-book in which she had a number of questions written, was conspicuous […] “Would Not Fight” […] A Voice asked how the workers were to live on £2 10s a week?
President Cosgrave—Are you living on £2 10s a week, or did you ever earn it?
A Voice—I have not got my breakfast yet.
Another Voice—The lady in the red hat will give it to him (laughter).

list.item:
Vartry—Callan, Rdwood,
Ashford, Broad Lough
Sea
Freeman’s Journal 25 Feb 1924-6
3: Water Supply
How Dublin and Districts Are Provided For
Visit to Roundwood A representative of the Freeman’s Journal was, by the courtesy of alderman Staines, Chairman of the Waterworks Department, and Mr. M.J. Buckley, Borough Surveyor, conducted over the extensive works at Roundwood which supply Dublin and several outlying districts […] The latest customer for the famous Vartry water is the Howth Urban District Council, and Mr. Buckley is making arrangements to convey it to them over a pipe line of no less than 34 miles.
On Saturday the water had risen to within a few inches of the top of the reservoir and was being blowing [sic] over the bye-wash.[…] the fact that when the reservoirs are full no less than about three thousand six hundred million gallons of water are impounded should be good news for the users.[…] History of the Work.[…] The basin of the river Vartry occupies the central portion of the north-east quarter of Co. Wicklow, and extends from the Sugarloaf and the Donce mountains in a south-easterly direction to the town of Wicklow.
The river has its source in the north end of its basin, and flows southward down the valley through the Callary district, on past Roundwood village, though the Devil’s Glen and the village of Ashford into the Broad Lough, and thence into the Irish Sea at Wicklow.
From source to sea it measures about seventeen and a half English miles, or less than one fourth of the length of the Liffey. On its way down the valley it receives many tributaries and with these it drains an area of nearly 35,000 acres, or a little more than four times the area of the city of Dublin.
The New Reservoir. Less than half this area is available for collecting water in the old Corporation reservoir, which is an artificial lake formed by the construction of a dam across the valley of the Vartry about ten miles from its mouth.
The new reservoir at Roundwood is a second artifical lake, formed by the construction of a dam across the valley about two and a quarter miles further north, or a little over twelve miles from Wicklow town and about twenty-four miles from Dublin.
The new reservoir and the old are distinguished as the North Reservoir and the South Reservoir respectively. The former is now full, and the 7S miles of the river, measured from its source to the new embankment, discharge the waters collected over the new by-wash or spillway into the tunnel about 672 feet long, which passes under the embankment and discharges into a canal cut through solid rock, over 1,000 feet in length, 30 to 40 feet in depth, and thence into the north end of the old or South Reservoir.
Note: Donce. Joyce’s note at (k) is very probably a response to the fact that this is a typo for ‘Djouce’.

The Carthusians were founded by St. Bruno, and the life of a Carthusian monk, like that of a Trappist, is purely contemplative.[…] Smoking is utterly eschewed, and the only spirit taken is a little Grande Chartreuse on New Year’s Day and after the “long walk” which occurs once a year and lasts all day.

Freeman’s Journal 25 Feb 1924-8
6 By the Way […] “Creased” In the Kerry murder trials just concluded it was stated in the evidence that when returning to Castleisland after the murder, one of the party remarked, “Don’t let on about the creasing of that fellow.” Whereupon another witness stated he did not know what “creased” meant. The late R. B. Townsend, in his interesting travel-book, “The Tenderfoot in New Mexico,” explains that creasing a horse is shooting him through the top of the neck, so as temporarily to paralyze the beast by grazing the spinal column. An inch too high and you miss him altogether; an inch too low and you kill him. Therefore, according to this interpretation of the word, “creasing” does not mean “killing.”

Freeman’s Journal 26 Feb 1924-9
3: Death After Shot
Brothers-in-Law on Trial for Murder
A Kerry Marriage The trial opened at the Dublin Commission in Green street Courthouse yesterday of John O’Neill and James O’Sullivan, charged with the murder of Michael O’Neill on June 19, 1922, near Killorglin, Co. Kerry.[…] Mr. Corrigan said that, unlike other cases that had been tried, this was a family tragedy, and the circumstances were most terrible when they considered that the principal witnesses would be the father of the prisoner O’Neill, and the dead voice of the prisoner’s mother, who made a deposition at the inquest and had since died. […] “Sullivan, You Shot Me.” […] Edward O’Neill, father of Michael O’Neill, deceased, said at one time he intended to give the farm to his son John, but the latter would not take it on the ground that it would not keep him. People named Curran came to the place to make a match with John, offering a fortune of £250. John ran away, and subsequently married Deborah Sullivan without his knowledge, getting no fortune with her. After the Marriage. After the marriage John’s wife returned to her home and John to witness’s home. Before John married, witness told him if he married the girl of the Sullivans he would not get a sod of land.

Piltdown man. This was widely believed to be a new genus of man, on the evidence of pieces of a fossilized human skull apparently found near Piltdown Common, Sussex, in the early 20C. In 1953 the evidence was proved to be fraudulent.

note.p: Note: Kish was an ancient city in what is now Iraq. The earliest monarchs of Sumer were called ‘Kings of Kish’, because this is where the gods established the first city after the flood.

list.item:
imp. catholic buddhist
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 280: la plus profonde, la plus “catholique” dans le vrai sens du mot, c’est-à-dire la plus répandue de toutes les religions, professée par près de 500 000 000 d’hommes, le bouddhisme, serait pour nous un insoluble problème. [the most profound, the most “catholic” in the true sense of the word, that is to say, the most widespread religion, practised by almost 500 million people, is Buddhism, which for us would be an insoluble problem.]
VI.C.3.093(o)

19 ^+32+^ counties
under 1 umbrella
Note: See illustration. ‘32’ appears to have been superimposed over ‘19’. During the debates preceding the Government of Ireland Act (1920) it had been proposed that there should be 9 Ulster counties, but it was finally agreed that there should be 6. If one adds to these the 26 counties which made up the Free State (and which now make up the Irish Republic) the result is a total of 32 counties for the island of Ireland.
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 284-5: Un Çoudra que les Pouranas nomment Tchandragroupta, et que nos savants identifient avec le Sandracottus à la cour duquel avait résidé le grec Mégasthène, tua le roi Nanda, le dernier rejeton de la dynastie kouravienne et réunit “sous un même parasol” les cent dix-huit peuples de l’Inde. [A Sudra called Candra Gupta by the Puranas, and identified by our scholars with the Sandracottus at whose court the Greek Megasthenes resided, killed King Nanda, the last scion of the Kouravien dynasty, and united “under the same umbrella” the 118 peoples of India.]
VI.C.3.094(a)

milk cows of heaven
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 308-9: Le père de famille, et, au besoin, la mère, invoque encore pour son propre compte et n’écoutant que son inspiration, les divinités distributrices des biens, mais le culte se détourne de plus en plus d’Agni et de Soma, les paisibles patrons du foyer, pour importuner Indra, le dieu atmosphérique, et Roudra, le chef souverain des vents (Marouts), qui, à la voix tonnante de l’orage, vont traire les nuées, les “vaches célestes”, pour arroser les semailles des Aryas. [The father of the family and, if need be, the mother, listening only to their own inspiration, invoke still for their own sake the beneficent divinities. But worship abandons more and more Agni and Soma, the peaceful guardians of the hearth, in order to disturb Indra, the air god, and Roudra, the sovereign chief of the winds (Marouts), who, accompanied by the thundering voice of the storm, go milking the clouds, the “cows of heaven”, in order to irrigate the seeding of the Aryas.]
VI.C.3.094(b)

note.p: Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 312: Il tombe bien, en moyenne, un peu plus d’eau dans la vallée du Gange, de la Djamna jusqu’à Bénarès, que dans celle de l’Indus, mais la quantité de pluie qu’elle reçoit n’est pas suffisante pour assurer les récoltes: dans les bonnes années, il est vrai, la fertilité du sol y est au moins égale à celle de l’Egypte et de la Mésopotamie; aussi l’Aryavarta oriental fut-il, de tout temps, une contrée peuplée au maximum, et, par suite, les sécheresses et les famines devaient y être au plus haut degré meurtrières. [It is a fact that, on average, a little more water falls in the Ganges Valley, and the Djamma Valley down as far as Benares, than in the Indus Valley. But the quantity of rain it receives is not enough to guarantee a harvest. It is true that in good years the fertility of the soil is at least equal to what is found in Egypt and Mesopotamia. Therefore, eastern Aryavarta has always been a region of maximum population and, as a result, droughts and famines must have been lethal to the highest degree there.]

Manmade of parts
of Brahma
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 288: Tous les savants s’accordent à dire que, même dans l’Inde, les castes étaient inconnues pendant la période ancienne: le seul passage du recueil des hymnes sacrés qui mentionne la division de l’humanité en branches distinctes, issues de différentes parties du corps de Brahma, est généralement regardé comme une interpolation. [All experts agree that even in India the caste system was unknown in the ancient period. The only passage in the collection of sacred hymns that mentions the division of humanity into distinct branches, deriving from different parts of Brahma’s body, is generally regarded as an interpolation.]
VI.C.3.094(d)

destiny cyclon in
Panjab = desolated
— tiger = crops eaten
by rodents
Note: A line separates this entry from the next one.
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 315: Ces Marouts, c’est-à-dire les vents qui, dans le Pandjab, trayent complaisamment les vaches célestes au-dessus des champs des Aryas, deviennent, dans les pays gangétiques, les terribles cyclones dont un seul a parfois coûté la vie à plus de cent mille hommes.[...] Aucun autre milieu ne fait mieux comprendre que vie et mort, bien et mal sont deux fleurs sur la même tige. Délivrez la vallée du Gange de ses cyclones destructeurs, son climat deviendra partout celui des teraï malfaisants; le tigre “mangeur d’hommes” protège les récoltes contre les myriades de rongeurs qui extermineraient par la famine la foule pâle des indigènes. [These Marouts, that is to say the winds which in the Punjab obligingly milk the celestial cows above the fields of Aryas, become terrible cyclones in the basin of the Ganges. There have been times when one such cyclone alone has killed more than a hundred thousand people. […] No other environment could make one better understand that life and death, good and evil are two flowers on the same stem. Free the Ganges Valley of its destructive cyclones and its climate would become like the malevolent Teraï throughout. The tiger, feared as a “man-eater”, protects the harvests against the myriad rodents that would annihilate the pale throng of the natives through famine.]
VI.C.3.094(e)-(f)

Rosy Brook he bought a book
Though he didn’t know how to spell it.
Such is the lure of literature
To the lad who can buy it and sell it.”
G. Bach. Brook.

Freeman’s Journal 27 Feb 1924-8
5: By the Way The night and morning of February 26 and 27 are the twenty-first anniversary of the most violent storm experienced in Dublin city and county for a whole generation. Towards midnight on the 26th, the wind began to rise to an alarming pitch, and soon it was tearing over the city and county, whirling slates, bricks and planks in all directions, shrieking with the weirdest of screeches, and literally tearing up giant trees by the very roots.

syrup of roses
Freeman’s Journal 27 Feb 1924-8
5-6: By the Way […] A Relic of Wellington At the auction of the stock-in-trade of Messrs. Evans and Co., Dawson street, Dublin, the “prescription book” of that once-famous dispensing firm had a historical interest, for it proved, inter alia, that the Duke of Wellington was born in Dublin, and not in Co. Meath, and also that the date of his birth was April 29, and not on May 1, as generally stated. Now, as a fact, under date of “Sunday, the 30th of April, 1760,” the entry in the prescription book runs:—“The following medicines were dispensed for the Countess of Mornington and her infant, the Hon. Arthur Wellesley,” duly signed by Sir Fielding Ould, Master of the Rotunda Hospital. Among the items for the infant child were a compound of fennel water, aniseed, manna and syrup of roses.
Not transferred.

6: By the Way […] La Dame aux Camelias The identity of Marie Duplessis with Marguerite Gautier—La Dame aux Camelias—has long been recognised, but additional particulars regarding the famous play are written in a recently-published book of recollections […] She was renowned for never being able to speak the truth, and justified herself to Stanislaus de la Rochefoucald by saying, “I like telling lies, because they keep the teeth white.”
?MS 47474-116, LMA: ^+: a pretty box of Pettyfib’s powder for Eileen Alannah to whiten her teeth: a whipping top for Eddy Lawless:+^ | JJA 48:055 | Mar 1924 | I.8§1.*2+ | FW 210.32

list.item:
snowdrop – candlemas
flower fair maid of February
Freeman’s Journal 27 Feb 1924-8
6: By the Way […] “Fair Maids of February” The reign of the snowdrop—“the first pale blossom of the unripened year,” as Mrs. Barbauld entitled it—is fast coming to a close. It has been practically the queen of the garden since the beginning of February, from which it also takes the more pious name of “Candlemas Flower,” the feast of “Candlemas,” or the Purification, occurring on the 2nd of the month. It has been remarked that, unlike other flowers, the blossoming of the snowdrop is little (if at all) influenced by weather conditions. With the beginning of February it is sure to appear, though the snow be on the ground; and even if “forced” in a green house, the blossoming refuses to be earlier.
VI.C.3.098(h)-(i)

clock stopped at wake
(Kerry)
Freeman’s Journal 27 Feb 1924-7
3: Kerry Murder
Brothers-in-Law Freed on Slaying Charge
Night at Wake
Failure to Stop Clock Offends Custom The trial was resumed, at the Commission in Green street Courthouse yesterday, before Mr. Justice Pim, of John O’Neill and James O’Sullivan, who are charged with the murder of Michael O’Neill on the morning of June 19, 1922, near Killorglin, Co. Kerry.[…] Changing Chairs […] William Joy, farmer, examined by Mr. Cullinane, gave evidence about attending the wake. He noticed a clock going. It was customary at wakes in Kerry to stop the clock. He was surprised.[…] James Macgillicuddy, a farmer of 20 acres […] saw the clock on the table. It was turned up-side down on the window, going. He never saw a clock going at a wake in Kerry before (laughter). Kerry Customs Mr McElligott—People might laugh, but people had their customs in Kerry. It was the custom in Kerry to stop the clock at a wake. It could have been turned down to stop it.
VI.C.3.098(j)

h what year was it
Freeman’s Journal 27 Feb 1924-9
5: “His Mind a Blank”
Remarkable Story told in Dail Court A strange story from the Co. Clare was told in the Dail Eireann Courts (Winding Up) Commission, when an action was heard before Commissioners Creed Meredith, Crowley and McDevitt, in which Michael Brew sought to set aside a deed whereby he purported to assign his lands of about 25 acres at Carianca, Kilrush, to John Brew in October, 1915.[…] Michael Brew, the plaintiff, and John Brew, the defendant, were relatives. Michael Brew had a holding of about 23 acres […] he continued to live with a very old aunt of his. “A Little Queer in the Head” About 1914 he got a little queer in his head. In March, 1915, his aunt died.[…] After that he acted after the manner of a man out of his mind.[…] For two years the plaintiff had been completely blank and about Christmas 1916 he awoke from his extraordinary stupor.[…] He saw a little girl and he asked her: “what place is this and what year is it?” This occurred in a room in the house of John Brew. Plaintiff next asked for clothes but he did not get them. “Kept in the House” During the years 1917, 1918, 1919 and 1920 he was kept in the house, and during that time not a soul in the Co. Clare ever saw him.
VI.C.3.098(l)

sacques

House by the Churchyard 1: We are going to talk, if you please, in the ensuing chapters, of what was going on in Chapelizod about a hundred years ago. A hundred years, to be sure, is a good while; but though fashions have changed, some old phrases dropped out, and new ones come in; and snuff and hair-powder, and sacques and solitaires quite passed away—yet men and women were men and women all the same—as elderly fellows, like your humble servant, who have seen and talked with rearward stragglers of that generation—now all and long marched off—can testify, if they will.
VI.C.3.100(f)

Czd poplars
House by the Churchyard 1: In those days Chapelizod was about the gayest and prettiest of the outpost villages in which old Dublin took a complacent pride. The poplars which stood, in military rows, here and there, just showed a glimpse of formality among the orchards and old timber that lined the banks of the river and the valley of the Liffey, with a lively sort of richness.
VI.C.3.100(g)

steep roofs
painted doors
House by the Churchyard 1: The broad old street looked hospitable and merry, with steep roofs and many coloured hall-doors.

dinner at 5
House by the Churchyard 1: The jolly old inn, just beyond the turnpike at the sweep of the road, leading over the buttressed bridge by the mill, was first to welcome the excursionist from Dublin, under the sign of the Phoenix. There, in the grand wainscoted backparlour [...] the Aldermen of Skinner’s Alley—a club of the ‘true blue’ dye, as old as the Jacobite wars of the previous century—the corporation of shoemakers, or of tailors, of the freemasons, or the musical clubs, loved to dine at the stately hour of five, and deliver their jokes, sentiments, songs, and wisdom, on a pleasant summer’s evening.

House by the Churchyard 2: and [I] wonder where the tables of the Ten Commandments, in long gold letters of Queen Anne’s date, upon a vivid blue ground, arched above, and flanking the communion-table, with its tall thin rails, and fifty other things that appeared to me in my non-age, as stable as the earth, and as sacred as the heavens, are gone to

cue ruffles
House by the Churchyard 2: Then there was the village church, with its tower dark and rustling from base to summit, with thick piled, bowering ivy. The royal arms cut in bold relief in the broad stone over the porch—where, pray, is that stone now, the memento of its old viceregal dignity? Where is the elevated pew, where many a lord lieutenant, in point, and gold lace, and thunder-cloud periwig, sate in awful isolation, and listened to orthodox and loyal sermons, and took French rappee; whence too, he stepped forth between the files of the guard of honour of the Royal Irish Artillery from the barrack over the way, in their courtly uniform, white, scarlet, and blue, cocked hats, and cues, and ruffles, presenting arms—into his emblazoned coach and six, with hanging footmen, as wonderful as Cinderella’s, out-riders and outblazing the liveries of the troops, and rolling grandly away in sunshine and dust.

House by the Churchyard 3: As for the barrack of the Royal Irish Artillery, the great gate leading into the parade ground, by the river side, and all that, I believe the earth, or rather that grim giant factory, which is now the grand feature and centre of Chapelizod, throbbing all over with steam, and whizzing with wheels, and vomiting pitchy smoke, has swallowed them up.

[…] There was a great flat stone over that small parcel of the rector’s freehold, which the family held by a tenure, not of lives, but of deaths, renewable for ever. So that my uncle, who was a man of an anxious temperament, had little trouble in satisfying himself of the meerings and identity of this narrow tenement; to which Lemuel Mattocks, the sexton, led him as straight and confidently as he could have done to the communion-table.
My uncle, therefore, fiated the sexton’s presentment, and the work commenced forthwith.

Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 321-2: Or, le “Fils du Ciel” compte parmi ses sujets tous ceux qui acceptent encore le calendrier de Pékin, qu’ils aient reconquis leur indépendance, ou qu’ils soient tombés sous le pouvoir de l’étranger. [But the “Son of Heaven” counts among his subjects all those who still accept the Peking calendar, whether they had recovered their independence or fallen under a foreign power.]
VI.C.3.102(b)

no surnames
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 322-3: Pourtant, à l’exception des ouvrages assignés à Confucius, l’historien n’avait guère à sa disposition que de rares généalogies ne pouvant remonter bien haut, puisque l’introduction des noms de famille en Chine date seulement des premiers temps des Tcheou. [Nevertheless, with the exception of works attributed to Confucius, the historian has at his disposal only a few genealogies, that do not go back very far because the introduction of surnames in China only dates from the first days of the Tcheou dynasty.]

dictated by toothless
grandfather to girl
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 325: On nous raconte qu’une fillette de neuf ans en [d’une des annales classiques de l’empire chinoise détruite par le feu] récrivit une partie sous la dictée de son grand-père, habitant la province de Tsi, et âgé de quatre-vingt-dix ans; le vieillard savait par cœur vingt-neuf chapitres du Chou-king, mais il n’avait plus de dents et ne pouvait se faire comprendre que de sa petite-fille. Je dois dire ici qu’il n’existe point d’ouvrage chinois dont on puisse s’approprier le sens, si l’on ne voit les caractères écrits, car l’idéographie chinoise s’adresse surtout aux yeux, et la langue écrite diffère essentiellement de la langue parlée. [We are told that a little girl of nine years old rewrote part of it [of one of the classic annals of the Chinese empire destroyed by fire] under the dictation of her grandfather, an inhabitant of Tsi province, aged ninety. The old man knew by heart twenty-nine chapters of the Chou-King but he no longer had any teeth and could only be understood by his grand-daughter. I must say here that there is no Chinese work that can be understood if one does not see the written characters because Chinese ideography is entirely visual and the written language differs fundamentally from the spoken language.]
VI.C.3.102(h)

Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 331: Les man-li, les “dix mille cérémonies”, ne répondent nullement à nos idées européennes sur l’étiquette et les cérémonies, [The Man-li, the “ten thousand ceremonies”, by no means correspond to our European ideas of etiquette and ceremonies,]
VI.C.3.102(j)

yellow E
blue H
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 343n1: Hoang-ho signifie litéralement “fleuve Jaune”, et ce nom s’applique très bien à ses eaux, chargées de ce löss, de cette “terre jaune”, étudiée par M. de Richthofen. Mais l’épithète de “fleuve Bleu” n’est donnée au Yangtse-kiang que par égard à certaines notions fondamentales de la cosmogonie et de la philosophie naturelle des Chinois. Yang, le principe mâle, actif, éthéré, lumineux, est un équivalent ou une attribution du ciel (tian); Yin, le principe femelle, est passif, opaque, et, par excellence, terrestre. Le Hoang-ho est le fleuve de la Terre (ti); le Yangtse, la progéniture du principe mâle, est de la nature du ciel. [Hwang-ho literally means “Yellow River” and this name is very pertinent to these waters, laden with löss, this “yellow earth” that has been studied by Mr. Von Richthofen. But the epithet “Blue River” was only given to the Yangtze in consideration of certain fundamental notions of Chinese cosmogony and natural philosophy. Yang, the male principle, active, ethereal, and luminous, is an equivalent or emanation of the sky (tian) and Yin, the female principle, is passive, opaque, and eminently terrestrial. The Hwang-ho is the river of the Earth (ti) and the Yangtze, the progeny of the male principle, is of the same nature as the sky.]
Note: Löss. Originally referring to a loose, fine and sharp-grained soil occurring in the Rhine Valley, this term has been extended to refer to any unconsolidated, non-stratified soil composed primarily of silt-sized particles. It is a very fertile agricultural soil.
VI.C.3.102(k)

note.p: Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 344n: Les premiers mots que les enfants chinois apprennent à lire dans le fameux Livre des Mille Caractères sont: “Le bleu est la couleur du ciel, le jaune est la couleur de la terre.” La première de ces propositions serait admise dans toutes les parties du monde, là même où le ciel est le plus souvent gris. [The first words that Chinese children learn to read in the famous Book of a Thousand Characters are: “Blue is the colour of the sky, yellow is the colour of the earth”. The first of these propositions would be accepted in all parts of the world, even those where the sky is more often grey.]

Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 346: Il y a une quarantaine d’années, ce bras [du Hoang-ho] se dirigeait vers le sud, emportant à la mer les eaux du Hoang-ho; mais un cataclysme, qui coûta les biens et la vie à des millions d’hommes, l’a rejeté dans le nord, justifiant encore une fois le surnom de “Fléau des Fils de Han” [Forty years ago this branch [of the Hwang-ho] turned towards the south, bringing the waters of the Hwang-ho to the sea. But a cataclysmic event, which took the properties and lives of millions of people, diverted it to the north, thereby justifying once more its nickname “Scourge of the Sons of Han”]

Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 357: Pourtant, à notre avis, nombre de circonstances paraissent établir que les civilisateurs du Céleste Empire y sont venus à l’état de barbares […] Mais la preuve la plus péremptoire nous semble fournie par le monosyllabisme chinois: le monosyllabisme, en effet, place cette nation absolument à part de toutes les autres nations historiques, [However, in our opinion, a number of circumstances would seem to establish the fact that the civilisers of the Celestial Empire had come there under barbaric conditions […] the most decisive proof seems to be provided by Chinese monosyllabism. In effect, monosyllabism utterly distinguishes this nations from all other nations in history.]

flowing water = Govt
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 363: Mais aussi, nul peuple n’a resserré autant que les Chinois les liens qui rattachent la formation des États au courant des fleuves: dans leur idéographie expressive, l’Eau qui coule figure le Gouvernement. [But furthermore, no people other than the Chinese has linked so closely the constitution of states with the running of rivers. In their expressive ideography, flowing water represents the government.]

Chalk Sunday
bachelor baiting
Lent
drawing the log
Waterford — Portlairge
Irish Independent 28 Feb 1924-6
5: Rounding up the Old Bachelors
Shrovetide Pranks The crusty old bachelor of the present day isn’t as thankful as he ought to be for the tolerance shown him at Shrovetide. Time was when the marriageable man who suffered Lent to arrive without coaxing some charmer to join him in the holy bonds, was made to pay the penalty of his neglect at this season. He became the butt of popular ridicule and scorn.[…] Marked Men! The first Sunday in Lent brought a new terror to the helpless bachelor. It was popularly known as “Chalk Sunday,” and for this reason. Impish lads lay in wait for unmarried men on their way to Mass, and marked a heavy streak of chalk on the back of their best Sunday coats. This was done to the accompaniment of the concluding words of some old rhyme like this:—”And you are not married though Lent has come.”
Chalk Sunday is still observed in parts of the South. Drawing the Log. Leave it all to Waterford, though, when it came to the question of dealing with delinquent bachelors at Shrovetide. The method employed was drastic and peculiar to that city alone. It was called “Drawing the Log,” the log being a heavy timber beam with a long rope attached. Astride this beam sat a fiddler, tipping our lively tunes, while all the old bachelors who could be laid hold of in the highways and byways of the city were rounded up and forced to draw it through the principal streets, to the malicious delight of the crowd. As one would suppose, “drawing the log” did not help the cause of peace and goodwill in Portlairge, and about a century ago it was discontinued.

appeared to expect stones
Irish Independent 28 Feb 1924-7
1-2: Woman Sentenced to Be Hanged
Brutal Kerry Murder […] For the murder of Mrs. M. O’Sullivan, at Cullooneymore, Killorglin, Kerry, on April 1 last, Easter Sunday, Hannah Flynn, domestic servant, was, at Dublin City Commission, sentenced to death. The jury recommended her to mercy. […] Wounds Described […] Mrs. H. Flynn said that about a month before the murder she saw Mrs. O’Sullivan driving a trap along the road. She saw accused clap her hands, with two other girls, and she also stooped as if looking for stones. Mrs. O’Sullivan appeared to expect the stones and drove on quickly.[…] Case for the Defence For the defence, Dr. Hackett, medical officer, Mountjoy, was examined. He said accused had her kept under special observation and he found she was of low intelligence, but was sufficiently intelligent to enable her to plead.

note.p: Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 136: Brugsch-bey et G. Maspero balayent toutes ces légendes; pour eux la civilisation, au lieu de suivre le courant du fleuve, l’a toujours remonté, et, dans sa marche triomphale vers le sud, fut longtemps arrêtée à Syène (Assouan), au-dessous de la première cataracte [Brugsch-bey and G. Maspero sweep all these legends away. For them civilisation, instead of following the river’s current, always went upstream, and, in its triumphant march to the south, had stopped for a long time in Syene (Assouan), below the first cataract]

list.item:
stone a
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 139-40: les pharaohs avaient eu l’idée de défendre par un mur de maçonnerie, la plus vulnérable de leurs frontières. On peut, à travers les âges, se rendre compte de l’épouvante que causa dans l’empire des pharaons l’apparition des pirates au casque d’airain: les villages, les villes même furent abandonnés; on se mit en toute hâte à fortifier le Delta; une garnison fut placée à Rhocotis avec ordre formel de tuer ou d’enchaîner tous les hommes venus par mer [the pharaohs had the idea of defending the most vulnerable of their borders with a masonry wall. One can, across the ages, imagine the terror caused by the appearance of bronze-helmeted pirates in the pharaohs’ empire. Villages, even cities, were abandoned. The Delta was hastily fortified and a garrison was established at Rhocotis with the formal order to kill or imprison any man arriving by sea]
VI.C.3.103(l)

X = Oun-Ouphr
Serapis
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 151n: Chreiste, traduction grecque d’Oun-ouphr, surnom de Serapis; Krystos des Alexandrins et le Christ des Evangiles, se confondent à tel point qu’il serait impossible de démêler la part légitime de chacun dans la grande fermentation des origines chrétiennes. [Chreiste, the Greek translation of Oun-ouphr, is the appellation of Serapis. The Krystos of the Alexandrines and the Christ of the Evangelists have been confused to such a point that it would be impossible to disentangle the legitimate part of either from the seething fermentation of Christian origins.]
VI.C.3.103(m)-(n)

Jordan
Not found in Les Grands Fleuves Historiques
Not transferred.

potamic
thalassic
oceanic
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 156: C’est ce qu’avait entrevu l’Allemand C. Böttiger, lorsque, dans la préface de son grand volume sur la Méditerranée, il écrivait ces lignes mémorables: “La Méditerranée fut ce milieu intermédiaire où s’effectua la transition des anciennes cultures fluviales, du monde potamique, celui que nous représentent encore aujourd’hui la Chine et l’Inde, etc., au monde océanique des temps modernes. Ainsi”, ajoute-t-il à la fin de cette préface où les trois milieux, tels que nous les avons retracés plus haut: fluvial ou potamique, méditerranéen ou thalassique et océanique sont déjà explicitement mentionnés [...]”. [the German C. Böttiger […] wrote these memorable lines in the preface to his large volume on the Mediterranean: “The Mediterranean was the intermediary milieu where was accomplished the transition of the ancient fluvial cultures—the potamic world of which China and India are still examples—into the oceanic world of our modern time”. At the end of this preface he adds, “And so the three spheres that we have recalled above have already been explicitly mentioned: fluvial or potamic, Mediterranean or thalassic, and oceanic […]”]
VI.C.3.104(a)

list.item:
identity of sex
Les Monstres Humains 65: Isidore Geoffroy-Saint-Hilaire nous dit qu’il existe une analogie complète, une identité absolue dans la sphère des organes génitaux pendant les premiers mois de la vie fœtale. Cette analogie étonnante vient à être encore plus frappante lorsqu’on vient à considérer le développement des organes génitaux externes. [Isidore Geoffroy-Saint-Hilaire has told us of the existence of a complete similarity, an absolute identity in the realm of genital organs during the first month of foetal life. This astonishing similarity becomes all the more striking when one considers the development of the external genital organs.]
VI.C.3.104(c)

note.p: Les Monstres Humains 105: Catherine de Médicis essaya à plusieurs reprises de faire des mariages entre nains et naines, mais elle ne parvint jamais à les faire procréer entre eux. L’électrice de Brandebourg, qui se consacra aux même soins, ne fut pas plus heureuse dans ses tentatives. [Catherine de Medici repeatedly tried to make marriages between male and female dwarves but she could never succeed in having them procreate. The Electress of Brandenburg, who devoted herself to the same task, was equally unsuccessful in her attempts.]
MS 47474-133, TsILS: No mutton ^+electress+^ at all. | JJA 48:067 | Jun 1924 | I.8§1.3 | FW 207.29

list.item:
giants weak eyes
Les Monstres Humains 104: il est démontré que ceux qu’on est convenu de désigner sous le nom de géants ont une intelligence très bornée; physiquement, ils sont mal proportionnés. La mollesse de leur tempérament les rend incapables d’entreprendre le moindre exercice; ils sont presque aussitôt excédés de fatigue; une lumière un peu vive affecte péniblement leurs yeux. [it is proven that those who are called giants have a very narrow intelligence. Physically, they are badly proportioned. Their constitutional indolence makes them incapable of the least exercise. They are almost immediately worn out; even a modestly bright light painfully affects their eyes.]
VI.C.3.104(d)

note.p: Note: See also 072(c).

? Les Monstres Humains 111: Il est à remarquer que les nains de naissance vieillissent jeunes et meurent vite et que la durée de leur vie est proportionnée à la petitesse de leur taille. [It is worthy of note that from birth dwarves grow old at a young age and die quickly and that the length of their lives is proportional to the smallness of their height.]

MS 47474-114, LMA: a judy queen, the height of your knee. ^+And look at her sharp and seize her quick for the longer she lives the shorter she grows.+^ | JJA 48:047 | Mar 1924 | I.8§1.*2 | FW 208.01-2

list.item:
born dwarf
became — ?
Les Monstres Humains 106: Selon Edouard Garnier, on doit diviser les nains en deux classes: 1° ceux qui se font remarquer par l’exiguïté de leur taille en venant au monde et restent petits toute leur vie, c’est-à-dire ceux qui naissent nains et restent nains pendant leur enfance et sont encore des nains à l’âge adulte; 2° les individus nés dans les conditions normales, subissant à un certain âge un arrêt de développement et restant, dès lors, toujours ainsi. [According to Edouard Garnier, dwarves are divided into two classes: 1) those who are notable for the their diminutive height on coming into the world small and who stay small their whole lives, that is to say they are born dwarves and remain dwarves during their childhood and are still dwarves in adulthood; and 2) individuals who are born in a normal condition but at a certain age become subject to arrested development and remain this way from then on.]
Not transferred.

H property
Not found in Les Monstres Humains but probably a response to (a).
Not transferred.

ligature limbs to
make dwarf
Les Monstres Humains 107: L’époque de la pleine floraison des nains est celle du Bas-Empire; ils pullulaient, c’est qu’à ce moment l’art venait en aide à la nature, car on les fabriquait. Le procédé consistait à donner à l’enfant aussitôt après sa naissance une alimentation insuffisante; il ne fallait pas longtemps pour qu’il devienne rachitique. C’était donc une désuétude artificielle qu’on amenait progressivement. On avait, à Rome, encore un autre moyen de faire des nains: on ligaturait les membres des nouveau nés et on les enfermait dans des caisses, de manière à paralyser leur développement. [The late Roman Empire was the period when dwarves flourished. They multiplied rapidly because at this moment art came to the aid of nature, for dwarves were being fabricated. The procedure consisted in giving a child an insufficient diet immediately after birth: it was not long before he became rickety. An artificial desuetude was therefore progressively introduced. In Rome there was yet another method for producing dwarves: the limbs of the newly-born were bound and sealed in chests in such a manner as to paralyse their development.]
Not transferred.

note.p: Les Monstres Humains 108: Henri II avait un nain du nom de Grand-Jean, il était d’une exiguïté extraordinaire, n’égalant pas néanmoins celle de ce Milanais qui vivait à la même époque et qui, pour s’affirmer mieux, se faisait porter dans une cage de perroquet, dans laquelle il était fort à l’aise. [Henry II had a dwarf called Big John, who was unusually diminutive, but he was in no way the equal of this Milanese who lived at the same time and who, the better to assert himself, had himself carried in a parrot’s cage in which he was quite comfortable.]
?MS 47474-125, TsILA: when he carried her home in a perokeet’s cage, | JJA 48:075 | May-Jun 1924 | I.8§1.3+ | FW 197.21-2

list.item:
dwarfs at French
court, buglers &c
Les Monstres Humains 108: Pendant longtemps, les nains furent très à la mode à la cour de France; dans le principe, ils ne servaient pas de simple divertissement, ils remplissaient des fonctions pour lesquels ils étaient rétribués. Ils sonnaient du cor sur le donjon du château où ils se tenaient, afin de signaler l’arrivée des dames et des cavaliers d’importance. [For a long time dwarves were very fashionable at the French Court. From the outset they were not just there for amusement, but performed offices for which they were paid. They sounded the horn on the castle keep where they were stationed, in order to announce the arrival of ladies and escorts of consequence.]
Not transferred.

note.p: Les Monstres Humains 112: En 1883, Louise Bichat mourait aux Sables-d’Olonne et les journaux d’alors rapportent qu’elle était mariée au sieur Callias depuis trois ans, sa taille ne dépassait pas 0 m. 80. “C’était une femme avec un tempérament de fer [...]. Elle avait avec son mari de fréquentes disputes. On dit même que pour avoir raison de ce dernier, quand tous les deux étaient ivres, elle montait sur une chaise, et croyez bien que ce n’était pas le mari qui avait le dessus.[…]” [In 1883 Louise Bichat died in Sables-d’Olonne and the newspapers reported that she had been married to a Mr Callias for three years and that her height never exceeded 0.80 metres [2 foot 7]. “She was a woman with an iron temperament […]. She frequently quarelled with her husband. It is even said that, to get the better of the latter, when both of them were drunk, she would stand on a chair and you can believe that it was not the husband who had the upper hand.[…]”]
MS 47474-107, LMA: Didn’t you spot her in her windeye ^+, standing up on a rickety chair,+^ pretending to play a tune or two | JJA 48:040 | Mar 1924 | I.8§1.*2 | FW 198.24

list.item:
13 causes of Monster
1) power of G
2) anger of G
3) demon
4) animal
5) enceinte
6) prophecy
7) example
8) stars
Les Monstres Humains 7: Dans un traité sur les monstres, Ambroise Paré examine les causes qu’entraînait la déviation organique chez l’homme et chez les animaux. Il en trouve treize: la première proclame la gloire de Dieu; la seconde indique sa colère; celles qui viennent ensuite ne sont que de grossières hypothèses empreintes de la plus grossière superstition. Dans la douzième, il admet que l’imagination de la mère peut être frappée et provoque chez elle une monstruosité. La treizième cause enfin est la participation du démon. [In a treatise on monsters, Ambroise Paré examines the causes of organic deformation in men and animals. He finds thirteen: the first proclaims the glory of God, the second marks his anger; those that follow are but crude hypotheses stamped by the grossest superstition. In the twelfth cause he claims that the mother’s imagination could be affected and this would result in a monstrosity in her. Finally, the thirteenth cause is the intervention of a demon.]
Not transferred.

note.p: Les Monstres Humains 10: Le jésuite Antonin Debrio, dans ses recherches magiques, formule les propositions suivantes: [...] “L’art magique peut faire naître des géants et des pygmées”. [The Jesuit Antonin Debrio, in his researches into magic, formulates the following propositions: […] “The art of magic can give birth to giants and pigmies”.]
