list.item:
devil takes hindmost
— — body of roué
ou pendu
Les Monstres Humains 10-11: Le chanoine Jules Serclier disait, en 1611, que le diable se mêle aux humains par commixion charnelle, en se formant un corps aérien ou bien en empruntant quelque carcasse d’un roué ou d’un pendu; c’est ainsi qu’il allèche les misérables et les rend criminels devant Dieu. [In 1611 the canon Jules Serclier said that the devil intermingles with humanity through carnal intercourse; by making for himself an aerial body or even by borrowing the corpse of someone broken on the wheel or hanged. In this way he seduces wretches and makes them criminals before God.]
Note: Proverb. The devil take the hindmost.
Not transferred.

monsters rare in birds
frequent in fish
Les Monstres Humains 12-13: Pline fait remarquer que les monstres sont d’une extrême rareté chez les oiseaux, ce qui serait dû, d’après lui, à ce que ces animaux sillonnent dans tous les sens les espaces infinies, et qu’ils ne peuvent se rencontrer que très difficilement. Pour les poissons, il en est tout autrement; en effet, la mer reçoit dans son immensité les germes qui tombent de ses mains fécondes et incessamment actives, et elle leur procure une alimentation riche et abondante; mais, comme les germes sont sans cesse agités par les vents et les flots, ils se mêlent entre eux et de cette confusion résultent des anomalies et des monstres. [Pliny notes that monsters are extremely rare among birds. According to him this may be due to the fact that these animals furrow infinite space in all directions and encounter one another only with great difficulty. For fish, it is otherwise. In effect, the sea receives within its immensity seeds from its fecund and ceaselessly active reaches and it provides them with rich and abundant nutrition. But since the seeds are perpetually agitated by the winds and tides, they intermingle and out of this confusion come anomalies and monsters.]
Not transferred.

Briareus Argus
Note: Briareus, Argus. Two figures in Greek mythology. Briareus was a giant with fifty heads and one hundred arms; Argus had one hundred eyes.
Not transferred.

sons of Seth
Les Monstres Humains 15: Paracelse dit aussi que le ciel, dans le principe, comprenait de grosses masses qui, par des influences astrales mystérieuses, furent converties en géants, nymphes, gnomes ou pygmées; quant à nous, humains, notre origine est exceptionnelle; nous sommes tous issus d’Adam, créé par les mains de Dieu, et nous n’avons rien de commun avec les constellations qui ont fourni la matière de ces géants. [Paracelsus also says that in the beginning the sky contained big blocks that, under mysterious astral influences, were converted into giants, nymphs, gnomes or pigmies. As for us humans, our origin is unique. We were all born of Adam, created by the hands of God, and we have nothing in common with the constellations that have provided the material for these giants.]
Not transferred.

black & white twins
Les Monstres Humains 18: La double conception n’est possible que si les deux fécondations différentes s’effectuent le même jour ou à un court intervalle; c’est ce qui constitue la superfécondation. Tel est le cas rapporté par Buffon d’une femme de Charlestown, qui mit au monde, en 1710, deux jumeaux de couleur différente, à la suite de rapports avec son domestique nègre, peu après la mort de son mari, qui était blanc. [Double conception is only possible if the two different fertilisations are accomplished on the same day or after a short interval; this is what constitutes superfertility. Buffon reported the case of a woman from Charlestown who, in 1710, gave birth to twins of different colour, after having had intercourse with her Negro servant shortly after the death of her husband, who was white.]
Not transferred.

Hippocrates defends
white princess who
bears nigger baby
Les Monstres Humains 19: une princesse athénienne fut accusée d’adultère, parce qu’elle venait de mettre au monde un enfant dont le corps était absolument noir; on supposait qu’elle avait eu des relations coupables avec un nègre. Hippocrate fut consulté; ce savant homme défendit l’honneur de la princesse et soutint que l’imagination de l’accusée avait pu être frappée pendant le cours de sa grossesse par la vue d’un portrait d’Ethiopien placé dans sa chambre; il prétendit que l’impression qu’elle éprouva avait imprimé au fruit qu’elle portait dans son sein une couleur semblable à celle du nègre. La princesse fut acquittée. [an Athenian princess was accused of adultery because she gave birth to a child whose body was completely black. It was presumed that she had had sexual congress with a Negro. Hippocrates was consulted and this wise man defended the honour of the princess and maintained that the imagination of the accused could have been struck during the period of her pregnancy by the sight of the portrait of an Ethiopian that had been placed in her room. He claimed that the impression she had experienced imprinted upon the fruit she carried a colour akin to the Negro’s. The princess was acquitted.]
Not transferred.

broken on wheel roué
Les Monstres Humains 20: Malebranche a raconté l’histoire d’une femme qui, se trouvant dans une position intéressante, ne craignit pas de se rendre à l’exécution d’un criminel qui devait subir le supplice de la roue. Ce spectacle jeta un tel trouble dans son esprit que, lorsqu’à quelque temps de là elle mit au monde son enfant, elle s’aperçut que les membres du pauvre petit étaient rompues aux mêmes endroits que ceux du roué au supplice duquel elle avait assisté. [Malebranche tells the story of a woman who, finding herself in an interesting condition, did not fear going to the execution of a criminal who was to undergo the torture of the wheel. This spectacle so disturbed her that some time later, when she gave birth, she noticed that the poor child’s limbs were broken in the same places as those of the criminal, whose punishment she had attended.]
Not transferred.

envie de fraises
Les Monstres Humains 23: Un préjugé très répandu est celui qui consiste à établir un rapport entre certaines anomalies et la forme, la disposition, la couleur, tous les aspects enfin d’un objet qui a impressionné, avec plus ou moins de vivacité, la mère dans le cours de sa grossesse; ainsi, qu’un fruit, une fleur, aient été ardemment désirés, et qu’on aperçoive sur le corps du nouveau-né une tache qui tranche sur le reste de la peau, on y verra l’image de ce fruit ou de cette fleur. C’est ce qu’on nomme une envie. [A very widespread prejudice consists in establishing a relation between certain anomalies and the shape, disposition, colour—in fact all the aspects of an object that has created an impression, to whatever degree, on the mother during her pregnancy. So if a fruit or a flower had been ardently craved for by the mother and if the body of her new-born child had a mark that stood out against the rest of the skin, one would see in it the image of that fruit or flower. This is what we call an “envie”.]
Note: Fr. Envie de fraises. Desire for strawberries or strawberry birth-mark.
Not transferred.

Holy Sacrament mark
Les Monstres Humains 24: Isodore Geoffroy-Saint-Hilaire rapporte qu’une enfant, qu’une dame pieuse venait de mettre au monde, avait sur un point du corps un saint sacrement très fidèlement dessiné! [Isodore Geoffroy-Saint-Hilaire reports that a child born of a pious lady had on one part of her body a most faithful depiction of the Holy Sacrament!]
Not transferred.

1 person in another
Les Monstres Humains 45: A côté des monstruosités doubles, se placent naturellement les cas où l’un des jumeaux, incomplètement développé, s’insère sur le ventre de l’autre ou reste inclus dans une partie de son corps. [Along with twin monstrosities there are cases in nature where one twin is incompletely developed and is inserted in the middle of the abdomen of the other or remains within some part of its body.]
Note: This is also suggested by some of the illustrations.
Not transferred.

very disagreeable impression
Les Monstres Humains 25: Iorkos a fait l’historique du monstre Hélène-Judith, d’après les notes de son beau-père Raggen; il raconte, entre autres détails, ce que ces deux sœurs soudées avaient dit elles-mêmes au médecin du couvent où elles furent élevées; elles avaient souvent entendu dire à leur mère que pendant qu’elle les portait dans son sein, il lui arriva un jour de voir deux chiens accouplés. L’auteur attribue donc la soudure des deux jumelles à cet événement, “car, dit-il, un tel spectacle dut produire une très désagréable impression sur l’esprit de la mère.” [Iorkos has given a historical account of the monster Helen-Judith according to the notes of his father-in-law Raggen. Among other details he relates what these two sisters, previously conjoined, told the doctor at the convent where they were raised. They had often overheard her mother saying that one day during her pregnancy she happened to see two dogs copulating. The author thus ascribes the conjoining of the two twins to this event, “because,” he says, “such a spectacle must have produced a very disagreeable impression upon the mother’s mind”.]
VI.C.3.104(e)

the look
12 Pound look
Les Monstres Humains 26: “Quand un monstre survient au sein d’une famille, dit Geoffroy-Saint-Hilaire, il étonne, excite et trouble toutes les imaginations.[...] Cette infortunée [la mère], sans songer que ses habitudes intellectuelles et ses connaissances très bornées la rendent peu propre à aborder un aussi grave sujet de méditations, ne se donne au contraire pas de cesse qu’elle n’ait découvert ce qui l’aura extraordinairement agitée durant sa grossesse et ce qui aura causé, par consequent, le développement désordonné de l’être que ses flancs ont porté.[...] Ces opinions particulières, conçues et propagées dans de semblables conjonctures, ont successivement servi à fonder la croyance populaire touchant l’influence des regards sur le développement d’un embryon. [“When a monster survives within a family”, says Geoffroy-Saint-Hilaire, “he surprises, excites, and troubles all the faculties of imagination.[…] This unfortunate person [the mother]—without imagining that her intellectual habits and her very limited knowledge makes her unsuitable to tackle such a grave subject of thought—unfailingly does not doubt that what had extraordinarily agited her during her pregnancy consequently caused the disturbed development of the being that her body had carried.[…] These particular opinions, conceived and propagated in similar unions, have successively served to establish the popular belief affecting the belief of the look upon an embryo’s development.]
Note: The Twelve Pound Look is a play by J. M. Barrie (1910). See JJII, 440.
VI.C.3.104(f)-(g)

note.p: Note: Fr. Chagrin. Grief.

Fr. Peau de Chagrin. Shagreen. A novel (1831) by Balzac, which tells of a magic piece of shagreen (ass’s skin) with the power to grant its owner’s wishes. However with each wish it shrinks and the owner’s life is progressively shortened. The phrase has passed into general use to denote something that is shrinking or disappearing. See also 069(j).

?Les Monstres Humains 27-8: Comment d’ailleurs concevoir cette prétendue action de l’imagination de la mère? Geoffroy-Saint-Hilaire a très bien démontré, d’après la proportion des enfants naturels aux enfants légitimes, que la contention d’esprit, le chagrin et les maladies qui en peuvent résulter ne doivent pas être considérés comme prédisposant une mère à mettre un enfant diforme au jour [Moreover, how can we understand this supposed action of the mother’s imagination? From the proportion of natural children to legitimate children, Geoffroy-Saint-Hilaire has very clearly demonstrated that the discord of the mind, grief, and illness that can result should not be considered as predisposing a mother to give birth to a deformed child]
?MS 47474-65, TsILS: the squidself which he had squirtscreened from the crystalline world grey darker and darker ^+waned chagreenold and doriangrayer+^ in its outlook. |JJA 47:443 |Jun-Jul 1925 |

list.item:
Galen — balls more than heart
to live well not to live
Les Monstres Humains 97: “Les testicules, dit Galien, sont plus précieux que le cœur lui-même; le cœur n’est utile que pour vivre, tandis que les testicules le sont pour bien vivre.” [Galen said, “The testicles are more precious than the heart itself: the heart is only useful for living whereas the testicles are there for living well.”]
VI.C.3.104(h)-(i)

crypt { orchid
didymes
ectopia
Les Monstres Humains 97: Ces organes [les testicules] sont au nombre de deux et le nom de didymes (doubles) leur a encore été donné.[...] Au début de la vie, les testicules sont situés près les reins, ils ne descendent dans les bourses qu’après la naissance. L’évolution des testicules peut être incomplète et ces glandes restent alors incluses dans l’abdomen; c’est ce qu’on appelle l’ectopie. Si cette anomalie existe d’un seul côté, ce qui est le plus fréquent, le sujet est monorchide; si elle est double, elle constitue cryptochidie. [These organs [the testicles] are two in number and the name didymes (doubles) has been given to them.[…] At the start of life the testicles are located close to the kidneys and only descend into their sac after birth. The descent of the testicles may be incomplete and these glands may remain enclosed in the abdomen: this is called ectopia. If this anomaly exists on only one side—and this is the most frequent case—the subject is monorchid. If it is double, this constitutes cryptorchidism.]
VI.C.3.104(j)-105(a)

demands all ballockless
Semiramis
Les Monstres Humains 98: L’origine de la castration se perd dans la nuit des temps les plus reculés. Si nous ajoutons foi aux récits de Marcellin et de Justin, la fastueuse reine de Babylone, Sémiramis, serait la première qui aurait imaginé de priver les hommes des marques de leur virilité pour mieux les asservir. [The origin of castration is lost in the night of the most remote past. If we give credence to the stories of Marcellin and Justin, the ostentatious Queen of Babylon, Semiramis, was the first to have conceived of depriving men of the marks of their manhood, the better to curb them.]
VI.C.3.105(b)

sui mutilation
Note: L. Sui. Of the self.
Les Monstres Humains 99: Les anciens prêtres de Cybèle se châtraient eux-mêmes pour être plus agréables à la divinité cruelle qu’ils avaient créée dans le délire de leur imagination et il fallut, pour mettre un frein à tant de ferveur, que Constantin et Justinien instituassent des peines sévères contre la suimutilation, en l’assimilant au crime de meurtre. [The ancient priests of Cybele castrated themselves in order to be more acceptable to the cruel divinity they had created in their frenzied imagination. To curb so great a fervour, it was necessary for Constantine and Justinian to institute severe penalties against self-mutilation by making it equivalent to murder.]
VI.C.3.105(c)

canis edit testes
Note: L. Canis edit testes. The dog eats testicles, witnesses.
VI.C.3.105(d)

nerve of thought
Les Monstres Humains 102: Des modifications particulières dues à la castration, la plus manifeste est sans contredit la perte de l’énergie morale.[...] “Il semble, dit Virey, qu’on ait coupé aux eunuques le nerf de la pensée.” [Of all the specific changes due to castration, the most patent is unquestionably the loss of moral energy.[…] Virey says that “It seems that one had cut the nerve of thought in eunuchs”.]
VI.C.3.105(e)

castor oil
Note: See also 166(j).

races — hair
skull
hue
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 82-3: Depuis le siècle dernier, on a souvent essayé de séparer le genre humain en groupes distincts et catégoriquement définis. Certaines de ces tentatives se basaient sur la coloration de la peau, et, cependant, nul ne songerait à déterminer d’après la nuance de son pelage à quelle race appartient un chien ou un cheval; d’autres classent les hommes d’après la section du cheveu [...]; d’autres encore d’après la forme du crâne [Since the previous century, frequent attempts have been made to separate the human species into distinct and categorically defined groups. Some of these attempts were grounded on skin-colour and yet no one would dream of determining which race a dog or horse belonged to on the basis of their fur-coat. Others classed men according the cut of their hair […] yet others according to the shape of the skull]
VI.C.3.106(g)

change language
— marry
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 83: les races se sont divisées, dispersées, mêlées, croisées en toutes proportions, en toutes directions, depuis des milliers de siècles; la plupart ont quitté leur langue pour celle des vainqueurs, puis l’ont abandonnée pour une troisième, sinon une quatrième; [races were divided, dispersed, mixed, and crossed in all proportions, in all directions, for thousands of centuries. Most of them abandoned their language for that of their conquerors only then to abandon that one for a third, if not a fourth;]
VI.C.3.106(h)

note.p: Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 86-7: Pour “élire” et “réprouver”, il lui [Dr Letourneau] suffit de diviser l’humanité en trois groupes, caractérisés en partie par la coloration plus ou moins foncée de la peau, en partie par les indices anatomiques, mais surtout par leurs rapports à la civilisation et à l’histoire: 1° La race noire [...] 2° La race jaune, mongole ou mongoloïde, de beaucoup supérieure à la première […] 3° La race blanche [In order to “elect” or “reprove”, it is enough for him [Dr Letourneau] to divide humanity into three groups, characterised in part by how dark the skin-colour is, in part by anatomical indices, but primarily by their relationships to civilisation and to history: 1) The black race […] 2) The yellow race, Mongol or Mongoloid, which is much superior to the former […] 3) The white race]

list.item:
Van Diemen’s Land
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 85: Puisque, dans l’histoire des civilisations, nous n’avons jamais affaire “à quelque peuplade bien isolée par des circonstances exceptionnelles, comme les Esquimaux du Gröenland ou les Tasmaniens de l’île Van-Diemen”, il devrait s’en suivre, de l’aveu de M. Topinard lui-même, que toutes les classifications anthropologiques du genre humain sont nulles et non avenues, du moins en matière sociologique et historique. [Since, in the history of civilisations, we have never had to deal with “any people isolated by exceptional circumstances, such as the Eskimos of Greenland or the Tasmanians of Van Diemen’s Land”, it should have followed, in the opinion of Mr Topinard himself, that all anthropological classifications of humanity are null and void, at least in matters of sociology and history.]
VI.C.3.106(i)

h Basque, Finn
or Hun
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 87-8: La majorité des peuples qui ont joué ou jouent actuellement les premiers rôles dans l’histoire universelle, sont, en effet, censés appartenir à l’un des grands rameaux sémitique ou aryen de la race blanche. Tels sont ou ont été les Aryas du Pandjab, les Iraniens, les Assyro-Babyloniens (en partie), les Phéniciens, les Hellènes, les Italiotes, les Gaulois, les Germains, ainsi que les peuples civilisés de l’Europe médiévale et moderne, à l’exception des Basques, peut-être des Finnois et des Hongrois. [Most of the peoples who have played or who now play prime roles in universal history are, in effect, deemed to belong to one of the great branches of the white race, whether Semitic or Aryan. Such peoples are or were: the Aryans of Punjab, the Iranians, the Syrio-Babylonians (in part), the Phoenicians, the Hellenes, the Italiots, the Gauls, the Germans, as well as the civilised peoples of Modern and Medieval Europe, with the exception of the Basques and perhaps the Finns and the Hungarians.]
VI.C.3.106(j)

always find someone
there before you
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 95: entrons dans cette Inde où le plus noble rameau de la race priviligiée des Aryas fit sa première apparition sur l’arène historique. A leur arrivée dans le Chapta Gandava, le Pandjab actuel, les Aryo-Hindous y trouvèrent déjà une civilisation plus avancée que la leur. [let us enter this India where the noblest branch of the privileged Aryan race made its first appearance in the historical arena. At their arrival in the Chapta Gandava—now the Punjab—the Aryan-Hindus already found there a civilisation more advanced than their own.]
VI.C.3.106(k)

criminals form end
?? old race
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 101: Le savant docteur italien [Lombroso] me semble avoir méconnu la grande portée scientifique de ces études [...] en appliquant à ces représentants dégénérés de l’humanité la dénomination assez malheureuse d’hommes criminels. Pour expliquer la présence de ce type barbare au milieu des plus opulentes cités de la moderne Italie, le Dr Lombroso a eu recours à une hypothèse des moins vraisemblables: Les habitués des prisons de Milan et de Turin se recruteraient surtout parmi les restes de quelque mystérieuse population aborigène qui, par l’effet d’un atavisme merveilleux, se seraient conservés jusqu’à ce jour à travers toutes les vicissitudes, les croisements, les émigrations. [The expert Italian doctor [Lombroso] seems to me to have misunderstood the vast scientific import of these studies […] in applying to these degenerate representatives of humanity the rather unfortunate designation of criminals. In order to explain the presence of this barbarian type in the midst of the most opulent cities of modern Italy, Dr Lombroso had recourse to a hypothesis that is most improbable: the inmates of the prisons in Milan and Turin must have been recruited from the remnants of some mysterious aboriginal population that, through a miraculous atavistic effect, would have been preserved up to the present, through all vicissitudes, interbreeding, and emigrations.]
VI.C.3.106(l)-107(a)

feel his pulse
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 108: Si pourtant les modernes habitants de Milet étaient encore animés de cet esprit qui, jadis, créa leur Thalès et leur Anaximandre, ils auraient, d’abord, opposé aux commotions lentes, mais irrésistibles du sol, cette même énergie que leurs prédécesseurs déployèrent contre Alexandre; vaincus dans cette lutte, il leur serait resté la ressource de transporter ailleurs leurs pénates et leur gloire: les golfes à courbe heureusement dessinée ne manquent pas dans le voisinage; mais le “pouls de l’histoire” avait cessé de battre dans cette artère avant que l’eussent comblée les boues de l’Akistchaï. [If however the modern inhabitants of Milet were still animated by this spirit that had once created their Thales and their Anaximander, they would have at first used against the slow but irresistible upheaval of their soil the same energy that their predecessors had displayed against Alexander. Having lost this struggle, they still could have transported their household gods and their glory elsewhere. The vicinity did not lack bays with felicitously delineated curves but the “pulse of history” had ceased to beat in this artery before the mud of the Akistschaï had filled it up.]
VI.C.3.107(b)

they emigrate before
flood & cold
?Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 115: Ainsi, d’après M. d’Assier, ce fut l’excessive rigueur des grands hivers de l’hémispère boréal qui obligea les populations des hauts plateaux de l’Asie à émigrer vers le littoral méridional de la Méditerranée, du golfe Persique, de la mer des Indes, dont le climat devait alors être similaire à celui des contrées les plus heureuses de l’époque présente. [Thus, according to Mr d’Assier, the extreme severity of the long winters of the northern hemisphere forced the populations of the high plateaux of Asia to emigrate towards the southern coast of the Mediterranean, of the Persian Gulf, of the Indian Sea, where the climate must have been similar then to that of the most fortunate countries in our present time.]
VI.C.3.107(c)

isothermal line
antipodal —
same event
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 122: Les lignes isothermes, nous l’avons vu plus haut, posent d’incontestables limites à ce que l’on peut appeler l’arène des civilisations historiques, mais ces limites sont assez larges et coïncident grosso modo avec les moyennes annuelles de +4° au moins, et de +20 ou 22° au plus. [The isothermal lines that we have seen above impose uncontestable limits to what we could call the arena of historical civilisations, but these limits are fairly broad and coincide approximately with the annual averages of at least +4° and at most +20° or +22°.]
VI.C.3.107(d)-(e)

average temp of
Irel = 10°
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 122: Les fils de la verte Erin, nés dans une île dont la température moyenne n’atteint pas 10°, prospèrent dans le district de S. Diego (los Angeles), sur les frontières du Mexique, bien mieux que dans la mère patrie, sous le joug du landlord anglais; [The sons of green Erin, born on an island whose average temperature does not reach 10°, prospered in the district of San Diego (Los Angeles), on the Mexican border, much better than they had in their homeland under the yoke of their English landlords.]
VI.C.3.107(f)

Freeman’s Journal 29 February 1924-5
7: Two Slain
Guest at Wedding Party Murdered
Leitrim Crime
Cavan Raiders Kill Son, Wound Father
Attackers Masked […] While wedding festivities were in progress at the house of a man named James Lynch, at Drumliffen, Gowel, James O’Brien, a brother of the bride, was murdered by armed men. The victim was a returned American.[…] Masked Men James Lynch, the newly wedded man, at whose house the festivities were being held, stated the men asked for “Poppy” Lynch. They were masked […] The masks worn by them were of brown paper.

DMP Watch
bulky
axe, rattle, lamp
felt hat
Freeman’s Journal 29 February 1924-8
5: By the Way The announcement of the “cut” in the pay of the D.M.P. makes it of interest to refer to their predecessors, the Watch, or as they were more generally known, “the Bulkies,” who, for many years before 1838, when the present force came into being, looked after the peace and order and lamps of the then much circumscribed city. The old police were attired in loose trousers, roughly-cut tunics; they wore high felt hats, carried a contrivance something like a pick-axe for defence purposes and for dealing with the oil lamps, and each possessed a rattle to give the alarm if an attack was made on him while going his rounds. This force had its main base at the end of Winetavern street, on Wood quay, and there were “stands” around the neighbourhood, generally outside the houses of the Watch Committee, which was a parochial affair.
VI.C.3.109(g)-(j)

bread tree
butter tree >>
VI.C.3.109(k)

liana rope
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 55: Dans ces régions moites et chaudes, en effet, croissent […] arbres à pain, arbres à beurre, dattiers, cocotiers et autres végétaux fournissant à l’homme le repas quotidien, l’ustensile où il le prépare, les fibres et les lianes dont il confectionne ses vêtements et ses engins. [In these moist and hot regions, indeed, grow […] bread trees, butter trees, date trees, coco-nut palms and other plants providing man with his daily meal, the utensils for its preparation, the fibres and the lianas with which he manufactures his clothes and his gadgets.]
VI.C.3.109(l)

capitals move N
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 58: M. Paul Mougeolle remarque avec raison que, à chaque période successive de l’histoire générale de l’Occident, les principaux foyers de la civilisation se sont de plus en plus éloignés du tropique pour se rapprocher du cercle polaire. [Mr Paul Mougeolle rightly notes that with each successive period in the general history of the West, the chief centres of civilisation move further and further from the tropics and come nearer to the Polar circle.]
VI.C.3.109(m)

h devoured partners
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 58-9: Tyr, Sidon, Athènes, Carthage, Rome ont succédé tour à tour aux villes subtropicales de Memphis, Thèbes, Our, Babylone, pour être elles-mêmes éclipsées par les capitales de la France, de l’Espagne moresque et de l’Europe centrale, auxquelles récemment se sont jointes Londres, Berlin, les grandes villes de la Suède et de la Russie. [Tyre, Sidon, Athens, Carthage, and Rome followed in turn the subtropical cities of Memphis, Thebes, Ur, and Babylon, to be then eclipsed by the capital cities of France, of Moorish Spain and of Central Europe, which have recently been joined by London, Berlin and the large cities of Sweden and Russia.]
VI.C.3.109(n)

‘law’
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 61: Pourtant, la constatation pure et simple d’un fait plus ou moins fréquent, mais sans liaison évidente et logique avec l’ensemble des phénomènes cosmiques, ne saurait avoir la portée de ce qui s’appelle une “loi” dans le langage scientifique de nos jours. [Nevertheless, the pure and simple verification of a fact that is more or less frequent but lacks any clear logical link to the range of cosmic phenomena would not have the scope of what we call a “law” in the scientific language of our days.]
VI.C.3.110(a)

geosphere
hydrosphere
atmosphere
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 62: Jetons un rapide coup d’œil sur les influences multiformes et souvent délicates que les différents rapports entre la géosphère, l’hydrospère et l’atmosphère, les trois parties constituantes de notre planète, exercent sur les destinées historiques et collectives du genre humain. [Let us take a quick look at the multiform and often delicate influences that the different relationships between the geosphere, the hydrosphere, and the atmosphere—the three constituent parts of our planet—exert on the historical and collective destiny of humanity.]
VI.C.3.110(b)

list.item:
Eng fog guarded
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 64: les brouillards et les courants des mers britanniques ont, au temps de “l’invincible Armada”, protégé la puritaine Angleterre contre le très catholique courroux de Philippe II. [the fogs and the tides of the British seas, in the time of the “Invincible Armada”, protected Puritan England against the most Catholic rage of Philip II.]
VI.C.3.110(c)

land due to
plant, animal
fish
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 67: Sans parler du rôle tout à fait capital joué par les céréales dans la préhistoire commune du genre humain, on pourrait citer, dans toutes les parties habitées du globe, de nombreux exemples de sociétés qui doivent leur constitution intime, voire leur existence, à quelque plante utile, à quelque inoffensif animal. L’exploitation des premières, l’extermination savamment organisée des seconds, pêche de la baleine, du hareng et de la morue dans nos mers septentrionales [...] forment, chez les peuples les plus civilisés, une des branches essentielles de l’économie nationale, et, chez les sauvages, la constituent presque en entier. [Without mentioning the altogether essential role played by cereals in the common prehistory of mankind, we can cite, for all the inhabited parts of the globe, the numerous examples of societies that owe their inmost constitution and their very existence to some useful plant or to some harmless animal. The cultivation of the former and the deliberately organised extermination of the latter, whaling, herring- and cod-fishing in our northern seas […] constitutes for the most civilised peoples one of the essential branches of their national economy and for the savages it constitutes it almost in its entirety.]
VI.C.3.110(d)

cows
reins } lead migrations
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 68: Les Tongouzes sont guidés dans leurs migrations par les rennes. Les chants védiques témoigneront éternellement de l’importance suprême qu’au seuil de l’histoire écrite du genre humain, les Aryas du Pandjab attachaient à la possession de leurs vaches [The Tongouzes are guided in their migrations by reindeer. The Vedic chants will eternally testify to the supreme importance the Aryans of Punjab attached to the possession of their cows, at the threshold of written human history]
VI.C.3.110(e)

Chinese thick as grains of
rice
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 68: La densité prodigieuse de la population de certaines parties de la Chine, de l’Inde, du Japon, dépend essentiellement de la récolte du riz. [The prodigious density of the population of certain parts of China, India, and Japan depends essentially on the rice harvest.]
VI.C.3.110(f)

opium spices
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 68: les épices et les essences précieuses ont amené les Européens dans l’archipel Malais. L’opium joue un rôle plus important—peu glorieux, il est vrai—dans l’histoire politique de l’Angleterre et de la Chine, que dans les traités de botanique et de pharmacie. [spices and precious oils brought the Europeans to the Malaysian archipelago. Opium played a more important role—not very glorious it is true—in the political history of England and China than in the treatises of botany and medicine.]
VI.C.3.110(g)

M ubique
at 5000 metre
dog follow — bark
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 69: l’homme, le plus parfait des êtres, a envahi toutes les régions du globe, depuis ces “enfers” de l’équateur thermique, où, comme dans le Fezzan, la chaleur, à l’ombre, dépasse parfois 50° [...] jusqu’aux hauts plateaux du massif himalayen où, à 5000 mètres d’altitude, le chien, seul de tous les compagnons habituels de l’homme, a pu s’acclimater, mais en perdant la faculté d’aboyer. [man, the most perfect of beings, has invaded all the regions of the world, from the “hell” of the thermic equator, where, as in the Fezzan, the heat in the shade sometimes exceeds 50° […] up through to the high plateaux of the Himalayan mountains, where, at 5,000 metres in altitude, the dog, alone out of all of man’s usual companions, could become acclimatised but at the cost of losing the ability to bark.]
Note: Lat. Ubique. Wherever.
VI.C.3.110(h)

Eng prints
Germ made
French name
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 71: A l’heure présente, on pourrait difficilement citer, des pôles à l’équateur, sous les longitudes les plus lointaines, sous les latitudes les plus variées, un pays de quelque étendue qui soit encore à l’abri de cette triomphante invasion de l’européanisme et ne connaisse point les missionnaires de l’Europe, ses armes plus ou moins perfectionnées, ses cotonnades anglaises, ses eaux-de-vie, généralement fabriquées en Allemagne et déguisées sous des noms français. [For the present, it is very difficult to find—from the poles to the equator, under the most distant longitudes, under the most varied latitudes—a country of some size that has been as yet sheltered from the triumphant invasion of Europeanism and without some knowledge of the missionaries of Europe, her more-or-less up-to-date armaments, the cotton goods of England, the spirits generally made in Germany but disguised under French names.]
VI.C.3.111(a)

Ir. ask for guns to
shoot E
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 71-2: D’autres, bien plus nombreux, opposent vainement à la conquête blanche une résistance opiniâtre et désespérée; d’entre ceux-là même, les plus avisés, les Chinois, par example, se voient, pour soutenir cette lutte inégale, réduits à demander à leurs adversaires une portion notable des engins de toute nature avec lesquels ils essayeront de les combattre. [Others, by far more numerous, vainly opposed the white conquest with an obstinate and desperate resistance. Among these, the most shrewd, for example the Chinese, in order to sustain this unequal struggle, find themselves reduced to asking their adversaries for a significant portion of whatever equipment with which they will endeavour to fight them.]
VI.C.3.111(b)

Pigafetta saw
human butcher’s
shop
sources de Nil
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 74: Près des sources de ce Nil qu’on croit, non sans raison, avoir servi de berceau à l’histoire universelle il y a une centaine de siècles, Schweinfurth a vu ces boutiques de chair humaine autrefois reproduites par Pigafetta dans un célèbre dessin [Close to the sources of the Nile, was believed not without reason to have served as the cradle of universal one century ago, Schweinfurth saw these stores that sell human flesh which earlier had been reproduced by Pigafetta in a famous drawing]
VI.C.3.111(c)

Meat!
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 74: les féroces Mombouttou passent encore leur vie en razzias, en luttes continuelles sous le seul prétexte d’approvisionner ces débits de cadavres. “Viande! Viande!” voilà le cri de guerre qui exalte leur courage par la promesse d’une immonde curée. [the ferocious Mombouttou still spend their lives raiding, in continual fighting, with the sole pretext of supplying these cadaver markets. “Meat! Meat!”, such is the war-cry that exalts their courage with the promise of vile quarry.]

Aujourd’hui comme au temps
de Pline et de Columelle ja
la jacinthe se plait dans les
Gaules, la Pervenche en
Illyrie, la marguerite sur
les ruines de Numance et
pendant qu’autour d’elles
les villes ont changé de
maitres et de noms, que
plusieurs sont entrées
dans le néant, que les
civilizations se sont choquées
et brisées, leurs paisibles
generations ont traversé
les âges et se sont succédé
jusqu’à nous, fraiches
et riantes comme au
jour des batailles”
Edgar Quinet >>
VI.C.3.114(a)-115(a)

Introduction à la
philosophie de l’
Histoire de l’Humanité
Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 124: Certes, en regard des rapides péripéties de l’histoire, les modifications du sol et de la climature s’accomplissent avec une imperturbable lenteur: “Aujourd’hui, comme aux temps de Pline et de Columelle, la jacinthe se plaît dans les Gaules, la pervenche en Illyrie, la marguerite sur les ruines de Numance; et, pendant qu’autour d’elles les villes ont changé de maîtres et de nom, que plusieurs sont entrées dans le néant, que les civilisations se sont choquées et brisées, leurs paisibles générations ont traversé les âges et se sont succédé jusqu’à nous, fraîches et riantes comme au jour des batailles.” Les Grands Fleuves Historiques 124n1: Edgar Quinet, Introduction à la Philosophie de l’Histoire de l’Humanité.” [It is true that, compared with the swift upheavals of history, the transformations of soil and climate take place with an imperturbable slowness: “Today, as in the time of Pliny and Columella, the hyacinth disports in Gaul, the periwinkle in Illyria, the daisy on the ruins of Numantia. And while around them cities have changed masters and names; while some have ceased to exist; while civilisations have collided with one another and shattered, their peaceful generations have passed through the ages and have come up to us, fresh and cheerful as in the days of former battles.”]
VI.C.3.115(c)

Guerard — Reflections on
Napoleonic Legend >
VI.C.3.116(i)

Historic Doubts respecting
N— B—
Whately 1826
Irish Statesman 1 March 1924-782
1-784
1: Literature and Life. The Propagandist as Myth-Maker Some of us are inclined to assume that propaganda was as much an invention of the Great War as tanks or mustard gas. Nothing could be more remote from the truth. Since wars began the propagandists have had not merely a finger but both hands in the pie. Their incitements nerved primitive man for the job of smashing his rival’s skull with a hammer, and the bards who squatted at tribal camp-fires exaggerating victories and minimising defeats were linked by a process of direct evolution with Lord Northcliffe at Crewe House or Radek at Moscow […]. To restore what they styled […] the Gaelic spirit [its] devotees […] failed wholly to see that if they were resolved to discard penny plain truths their two-penny coloured fictions should be turned out with some attention to detail.[…] How the business was handled by the supreme master of the craft in historic times is analysed with pungent force and witty insight in Professor A. L. Guérard’s Reflections on the Napoleonic Legend. (Fisher Unwin, 15
-).[…] Five years after Waterloo, the future Archbishop Whately had written his Historic Doubts Relative to Napoleon Buonaparte to show that the discrepancies between the alleged facts and the actual evidence made the whole story so fantastic as to strain honest belief.
VI.C.3.116(j)

Melanesian
chow
blond beast
Irish Statesman 1 March 1924-788
1-789
1: Reviews.
Isles of Illusion. Anonymous; with a foreword and Edited by Bohun Lynch. (London: Constable & Co.) […] the anonymous writer of the letters which make up Isles of Illusion is by no means a fresh soul.[…] Add to this that he is an Oxford man for whom the Melanesians are “niggers” and for whom the imported Chinese are “Chows,” and you will perceive that he has many cycles to go through before he becomes a fresh soul.[…] European man never showed more of the blond beast than in his prowling through the South Seas.[…] “It is an awful pity,” says the writer of Isles of Illusion, “that the real Tahitian language is practically extinct. No one speaks it, and only the old people of very noble blood understand it. It is an awful bastard tongue that is spoken now; it has lost all the lovely old words, for example, descriptive of the different kinds of fear that come by night. Fortunately an old French priest has taken the trouble to write a grammar and dictionary of the ancient tongue.”
VI.C.3.116(l)-117(a)

twilight reveries

2: Reviews.[…] Twilight Reveries. By Louis J. Walsh. (Dublin. M.H. Gill. 3
6.)
Note: Louis J. Walsh (1880-1941). Known to Joyce while they were both students in University College, Dublin. In the Literary and Historical Society, in addition to winning the gold medal for oratory over Joyce, he defeated Joyce’s bid to become treasurer. He was also the author of the never-to-be-forgotten lines beginning ‘Art thou real, my Ideal’, which appear in Stephen Hero (83). See also My Brother’s Keeper, 165-6.

VI.C.3.118(n)

bishop –
pres to III (consecrati)
Note: A line connects the Roman numeral to the final word.
It. Consecrati. Consecrated (plural). Traditionally, when a new bishop has to be chosen, three candidates are proposed by different bodies within the church. When he is consecrated, this is done by three bishops of his own choice.
VI.C.3.119(a)-(b)

lies prone
gospels on shoulders
CE 278b, ‘Consecration’: The Litany of the Saints is now recited or chanted, while the elect lies prostrate on the floor of the sanctuary and all the others kneel. […] The consecrator, aided by the assistant bishops, takes the book of the Gospels and, opening it, places it on the neck and shoulders of the elect
VI.C.3.119(c)-(d)

cincture
CE 278a, ‘Consecration’: The consecrator is vested in full pontificals of the colour of the Mass of the day; the assistant bishops, in amice, stole, and cope of the same colour, and a white linen or damask mitre; the bishop-elect in amice, alb, cincture, white stole crossed on the breast, and cope and biretta.
VI.C.3.119(e)

ring 3rd of R
CE 279a, ‘Consecration’: The consecrator then blesses the ring and places it on the third finger of the bishop’s right hand, reminding the latter that it is the symbol of fidelity which he owes to Holy Church.
VI.C.3.119(f)

scalp cleaned
with crumbs
CE 279a, ‘Consecration’: He then receives the kiss of peace from the consecrator and the assistant bishops, and the latter conduct him to his altar, where the crown of his head is cleansed with crumbs of bread, and his hair is adjusted.
VI.C.3.119(g)

present 2 torches
2 loaves
2 barrels wine
CE 279a, ‘Consecration’: After the Offertory the new bishop is led to the consecrator’s altar where he presents to the latter two lighted torches, two loaves of bread, and two small barrels of wine.
VI.C.3.119(h)

G man: Geraldine
embroidered on chest
Note: G Man. A detective working from the ‘G’ division (the plainclothes intelligence division) of the Dublin Metropolitan Police. See U 8.420, 12.271.
Geraldines. The Fitzgerald family, earls of Desmond and Kildare throughout the medieval and early modern period. Followers of the Geraldines had a G. embroidered on their breast.
VI.C.3.119(i)-(j)

15 crown Mary’s Abbey, carried
through Dub on shoulders
of Great Darcy of Platten
turnspit, falconer
Note: Lambert Simnel. Pretender. See Samuel A. Ossary Fitzpatrick’s Dublin, 45: In 1487 Gerald Fitzgerald, eighth Earl of Kildare, adopted the pretender Lambert Simnel, who had landed in Ireland, and who was joined there by the exiled Lord Lovel, and by the Earl of Lincoln, nephew of Edward IV., and declared by Richard III. to be his heir. The Earl of Kildare […] and ‘[…] other great men of quality’ … ‘in all haste assembled at Divelin’ (Dublin), on Whitsunday, 24th May, ‘and there in Christchurch they crowned this Idoll […]’ The crown used on this occasion is said to have been taken from the statue of the Virgin in the Church of Sainte Marie del Dam, and the ‘tall man’ who carried the new-crowned king to the Castle was a huge Anglo-Irishman known as ‘Great D’Arcy of Platten.’ The pretender crossed to Lancashire […] but was utterly defeated at Stoke, and relegated to the royal kitchen as a scullion or turnspit.
Simnel receives a passing mention in U 3.315-16. See also VI.C.11.144 (VI.D.6.144), identified by Danis Rose as a positively grotesquely distorted macromass of virtually the same note, taken from Peter’s Dublin Fragments 10: ‘little Lambert Simnell was carried on the shoulders of big D'Arcy of Platten from the Castle to be crowned at Christ Church Cathedral as Edward VI., and the child imposter wore a crown taken from a statue of Mary le Dam.’ The Dublin Fragments does not mention Simnel’s subsequent career as scullion and is not a source for the present notebook. Simnell was fifteen at the time of his coronation. After the revolt was put down he was spared and appointed to the office of turnspit, later promoted to that of falconer.

graveyard, —priest
Irish Independent 3 March 1924-8
7: Items of Interest […] Carey’s Grave Discovered. The erection of a refuse destructor at Port Elizabeth has, says a Reuters message from Capetown, led to the rediscovery of a link with the historic Phoenix Park tragedy of 1882—the grave of the informer, Carey, who fled to South Africa in the liner Melrose. In this ship also travelled James O’Donnell, who had sworn to avenge the man whom Carey’s treachery had sent to the gallows. O’Donnell waited patiently until they arrived at Delagoa Bay, when he calmly shot Carey on deck. Carey was buried in a convict cemetery, as no priest would officiate at the burial.

Note: See EB11 ‘Twelve Tables’, 491c: ‘the tables of wood on which was engraved or painted the earliest codification of Roman law. Originally ten in number, two others were afterwards added, containing supplemental matter, and the whole code was termed the Lex XII. Tabularum (Law of the Twelve Tables).’ The Twelve Tables are constantly referred to in Vico. See especially New Science 1001, where the Twelve tables are discussed in the context of the different perceptions of law held by plebians and patricians.

Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 438n4: Dion Cassius, l. lxix. The exile of the Jewish nation from Jerusalem is attested by Aristo of Pella, (apud Euseb. l. iv. c. 6,) and is mentioned by several ecclesiastical writers; though some of them too hastily extend this interdiction to the whole country of Palestine.

Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 438: The Nazarenes retired from the ruins of Jerusalem to the little town of Pella beyond the Jordan, where that ancient church languished above sixty years in solitude and obscurity. 19
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 438n3: Eusebius, l. iii. c. 5. Le Clerc, Hist. Ecclesiast. p. 605. During this occasional absence, the bishop and church of Pella still retained the title of Jerusalem. In the same manner, the Roman pontiffs resided seventy years at Avignon; and the patriarchs of Alexandria have long since transferred their episcopal seat to Cairo.

Note: The Jersey Devil. Part of the folklore of the New Jersey Pinelands, a mythical diabolical creature said to haunt the Jersey Pine Barrens, mutilating animals and bringing bad luck. There are many different accounts of its origin. According to the most popular, it was the 13th child of a Mrs. Shrouds of Leeds Point, NJ—the result of a rash oath on her part, that if she had another child it would be a devil.

list.item:
40 hours

Freeman’s Journal 5 March 1924-8
5: By the Way The period at which the fast of Ash Wednesday was instituted is uncertain, but we do know that in the Latin Church Lent formerly lasted but thirty-six days. It was in the fifth century that four days were added in imitation of the forty days fast of the Saviour, and this usage has been maintained ever since. […] The Lenten Season. “Lent,” they say, is derived from a Saxon word signifying “Spring.”
Note: ‘Lenz’ does not appear in the article, but is a poetic German word for ‘Spring’ also related to the Saxon word lentin, referred to (but not actually mentioned) above. The German and English forms have both been connected with derivatives of words for ‘long’, referring to the lengthening of the days.

End of World
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 452: In the primitive church the influence of truth was very powerfully strengthened by an opinion which, however it may deserve respect for its usefulness and antiquity, has not been found agreeable to experience. It was universally believed that the end of the world, and the kingdom of heaven, were at hand.
VI.C.3.125(m)

rMilleniumr
workday
A.M. 6000
+ 1000 Sabbath
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 453-4: The ancient and popular doctrine of the Millennium was intimately connected with the second coming of Christ. As the works of the creation had been finished in six days, their duration in their present state, according to a tradition which was attributed to the prophet Elijah, was fixed to six thousand years. By the same analogy it was inferred that this long period of labor and contention, which was now almost elapsed, would be succeeded by a joyful Sabbath of a thousand years; and that Christ, with the triumphant band of the saints and the elect who had escaped death, or who had been miraculously revived, would reign upon earth till the time appointed for the last and general resurrection.
Note: A.M. Anno Mundi. Year of the world, dating from the creation.

Blarney } SP
Note: Blarney. Fluency in cajoling talk, supposedly conferred on all who kiss the Blarney Stone, in Blarney Castle, Co. Cork.
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 458: The supernatural gifts, which even in this life were ascribed to the Christians above the rest of mankind, must have conduced to their own comfort, and very frequently to the conviction of infidels. Besides the occasional prodigies, which might sometimes be effected by the immediate interposition of the Deity when he suspended the laws of Nature for the service of religion, the Christian church, from the time of the apostles and their first disciples, has claimed an uninterrupted succession of miraculous powers, the gift of tongues, of vision, and of prophecy, the power of expelling dæmons, of healing the sick, and of raising the dead.
VI.C.3.126(a)-(b)

exorcism
demon confesses
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 459: The awful ceremony was usually performed in a public manner, and in the presence of a great number of spectators; the patient was relieved by the power or skill of the exorcist, and the vanquished dæmon was heard to confess that he was one of the fabled gods of antiquity, who had impiously usurped the adoration of mankind.
VI.C.3.126(c)-(d)

healing
†ian science
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 459: The primitive Christians perpetually trod on mystic ground, and their minds were exercised by the habits of believing the most extraordinary events. They felt, or they fancied, that on every side they were incessantly assaulted by dæmons, comforted by visions, instructed by prophecy, and surprisingly delivered from danger, sickness, and from death itself, by the supplications of the church.
Note: Christian Science. Here an extrapolation suggested by the source and referring to the Church of Christ the Scientist, founded on the principles of Mary Baker Eddy. Its adherents regard sickness as an error, curable by the healing teachings of Jesus Christ.
VI.C.3.126(e)-(f)

S P narrates sui miracles
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 460n1: It may seem somewhat remarkable that Bernard of Clairvaux, who records so many miracles of his friend St. Malachi, never takes any notice of his own, which, in their turn, however, are carefully related by his companions and disciples. In the long series of ecclesiastical history, does there exist a single instance of a saint asserting that he himself possessed the gift of miracles?
VI.C.3.126(g)

miracles cease to grow
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 460: If the truth of any of those miracles is appreciated by their apparent use and propriety, every age had unbelievers to convince, heretics to confute, and idolatrous nations to convert; and sufficient motives might always be produced to justify the interposition of Heaven. And yet, since every friend to revelation is persuaded of the reality, and every reasonable man is convinced of the cessation, of miraculous powers, it is evident that there must have been some period in which they were either suddenly or gradually withdrawn from the Christian church.
VI.C.3.126(h)

Tertullian forbids
shave (lie v face)
white bread
foreign wine
soft pillow
false hair
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 465: In their censures of luxury the fathers are extremely minute and circumstantial; and among the various articles which excite their pious indignation, we may enumerate false hair, garments of any color except white, instruments of music, vases of gold or silver, downy pillows, (as Jacob reposed his head on a stone,) white bread, foreign wines, public salutations, the use of warm baths, and the practice of shaving the beard, which, according to the expression of Tertullian, is a lie against our own faces, and an impious attempt to improve the works of the Creator.
VI.C.3.126(i)

whimsical laws imposed
on marriage bed wd force
a smile from the young
& a blush — — fair
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 466: The use of marriage was permitted only to his fallen posterity, as a necessary expedient to continue the human species, and as a restraint, however imperfect, on the natural licentiousness of desire. The hesitation of the orthodox casuists on this interesting subject betrays the perplexity of men, unwilling to approve an institution which they were compelled to tolerate. The enumeration of the very whimsical laws, which they most circumstantially imposed on the marriage-bed, would force a smile from the young and a blush from the fair.
VI.C.3.126(j)-127(a)

priests & nun sleep to
defy z
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 467: Some were insensible and some were invincible against the assaults of the flesh. Disdaining an ignominious flight, the virgins of the warm climate of Africa encountered the enemy in the closest engagement; they permitted priests and deacons to share their bed, and gloried amidst the flames in their unsullied purity.
VI.C.3.127(b)

Rome 2 apostles
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 475: The society of the faithful bore a just proportion to the capital of the empire; and the Roman church was the greatest, the most numerous, and, in regard to the West, the most ancient of all the Christian establishments, many of which had received their religion from the pious labors of her missionaries. Instead of one apostolic founder, the utmost boast of Antioch, of Ephesus, or of Corinth, the banks of the Tiber were supposed to have been honoured with the preaching and martyrdom of the two most eminent among the apostles; and the bishops of Rome very prudently claimed the inheritance of whatsoever prerogatives were attributed either to the person or to the office of St. Peter.
VI.C.3.127(c)

angel bishop
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 471n3: See the introduction to the Apocalypse. Bishops, under the name of angels, were already instituted in the seven cities of Asia. And yet the epistle of Clemens (which is probably of as ancient a date) does not lead us to discover any traces of episcopacy either at Corinth or Rome.
VI.C.3.127(d)

with equal fury &
devotion
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 476: If this Punic war [between the churches of Rome and Carthage] was carried on without any effusion of blood, it was owing much less to the moderation than to the weakness of the contending prelates. Invectives and excommunications were their only weapons; and these, during the progress of the whole controversy, they hurled against each other with equal fury and devotion.
VI.C.3.127(e)

Comm. of goods
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, I, (Chapter XV) 477: The community of goods, which had so agreeably amused the imagination of Plato, and which subsisted in some degree among the austere sect of the Essenians, was adopted for a short time in the primitive church. The fervor of the first proselytes prompted them to sell those worldly possessions, which they despised, to lay the price of them at the feet of the apostles, and to content themselves with receiving an equal share out of the general distribution. The progress of the Christian religion relaxed, and gradually abolished, this generous institution, which, in hands less pure than those of the apostles, would too soon have been corrupted and abused by the returning selfishness of human nature; and the converts who embraced the new religion were permitted to retain the possession of their patrimony, to receive legacies and inheritances, and to increase their separate property by all the lawful means of trade and industry.
VI.C.3.127(f)

Ty Gwyn
white House

Fr. Mettre la charrue avant les bœufs (to put the plough before the oxen) is the the French equivalent of the ‘putting the cart before the horse.’ See next.

Dane’s Cast
Note: Described on maps as the Dane’s Cast, a wall around Ulster begins in the east near Scarva on the Down-Armagh border; the next section, known as the Dorsey, stands at Drummill Bridge in south Armagh; it continues into Monaghan near Muckno Lake, where it is known either as the Worm Ditch or as the Black Pig’s Dyke; and further short stretches extend through Cavan and Fermanagh to Donegal Bay. The road from Tara to Enchain Maha passed through the fortifications of ‘The Dorsey’, which means The Gate.
VI.C.3.129(m)

VI.C.3.133(f)

rpartitionr
— Donegal
rwavy line
Note: Partition. The division of Ireland into two separate jurisdictions, each with its own parliament, one in Belfast for a number of counties in Ulster and one in Dublin for the remaining counties in Ulster and in the other three provinces. At first it was envisaged that all nine counties of Ulster would be separate, but it was finally agreed that Cavan, Monaghan and Donegal should be governed by Dublin. Under the Anglo-Irish Treaty of 1921 a Boundary Commission was set up to determine the boundary of Northern Ireland, taking into account not just the wishes of the population, but economic, historical and geographical factors as well. It did not meet until 1924 and it was to break up in disarray by the end of the following year. In the meantime newspapers of the period published endless debates about how the country should be divided and where the lines of demarcation should fall. In this context the last part of the present unit very probably refers to the boundary line east of Donegal, which would divide it from Northern Ireland.

note.p:
Connacht Tribune 8 March 1924-3
3-4: The West of Ireland.
Mr. P. O’Maille’s Interesting Paper […] The series of benificent Land Acts which commenced with the Act of 1881 came rather late to produce notable improvements so far. The age-long struggle of the tenants with those adverse conditions which in most cases never allowed them to rise much above the poverty line, and resulted in the emigration of the young and strong, were so discouraging that one wonders […] not why progress has been so slow but how the considerable progress which has been made by those who “stuck to the sod” was at all possible.

Connacht Tribune 8 March 1924-3
3-4: The West of Ireland.
Mr. P. O’Maille’s Interesting Paper Galway has been referred to as “a noted empire of great fame with foreign merchants.” […] the records of the city showed that in the year 1615 upwards of 1,200 tons of Spanish wine “were landed here for account of the merchants of Galway.”

lay an egg >

farmers object to poultry
Connacht Tribune 8 March 1924-3
3-5: The West of Ireland
Mr. P. O’Maille’s Interesting Paper […] Legacy of the Brehon Laws. In most parts of the West of Ireland poultry rearing—not for the table but for the production of eggs—is very profitable […] One of the remarkable things about poultry-keeping generally is the aversion to it of the male members of the family. So great is the opposition of the farmer to the presence of fowl of any description about the place, that in many cases it cannot be kept at all, and when it is tolerated it is often the cause of unpleasantness.

item.seg:
I am brought up
under an old act
of Edw III

note.p:
Connacht Tribune 8 March 1924-7
5: Publicans and Guard […] “A Courting Expedition.” […] Preferred the Alternative Catherine Reilly, Deerpark, Ballinasloe, summoned John Keogh, an ex-internee of the same place, for abusive and threatening language on 25th February.—Mr. Colohan, solr., appeared for plaintiff, and defendant conducted his own case.
Plaintiff, answering her solicitor, said she lived at Deerpark. She remembered the night in question. She was in her own house at the time with her children. John Keogh came along and used filthy names towards her and threatened her, saying he would put her off the roads. He was at the back door and he seemed to have drink taken. Later on somebody came along and stones were thrown at the house. Her husband got up, dressed himself and went outside. She was afraid of the defendant as he came outside her house night after night and threatened to kill her.[…] Defendant, in cross-examination: Do you know that this was pay day for your husband, who works at the asylum?—Plaintiff: I don’t know what you mean.—Defendant: Commonly known as the day the “cow calves” (laughter). —Defendant: Did you bring home a jar of porter that day?—Plaintiff: My husband belongs to the temperance league (laughter).—Had you a man named O’Neill with you that night?—Plaintiff: I did not see the man for six months.—Did you change a postal order for him that day?
Mr. Colohan: What has this to do with it?—Defendant: I will show that it was this man who fired the shots. (to Plaintiff): Was this man in your house that night?—Defendant [error for ‘Plaintiff’ in source]: No. […]—You know this fellow O’Neill?—Well I saw him coming into the house.—Do you do his washing? (laughter).—No, I do not.—Did you buy the usual jar of porter this pay night and put your husband sitting down with it before the fire while you went “rampaging” round the roads with this fellow, O’Neill? (laughter).—I have not seen O’Neill for six months.
Your husband is not a warlike man?—No, he is a quiet man.—Why did he run out on the road when he heard the shots fired?—No answer. […] Mr. Colohan: I will put the husband up to give evidence of the abuse, your worship.
Defendant: I object, as I don’t think you can examine the husband in this case (laughter). I am brought up under an old Act of Edward III, which is defunct (renewed laughter).

riposta
Note: It. Sapienza poetica, sapienza riposta. Poetic wisdom, esoteric wisdom.
EB11, ‘Vico’, 24b-c: As already stated, the Scienza nuova appeared in three different editions […] Its fundamental idea consists in that which Vico, in his peculiar terminology, styles “poetical wisdom” (sapienza poetica) and “occult wisdom” (sapienza riposta) and in the historical process by which the one is merged in the other.[…] poetical wisdom, appearing as a spontaneous emanation of the human conscience, is almost the product of divine inspiration. From this, by the aid of civilization, reason and philosophy, there is gradually developed the civil, occult wisdom. The continual, slow and laborious progress from the one to the other is that which really constitutes history.

Note: It. Fulmini, aquile. Lightnings, eagles. These are both aspects of Jove discussed by Vico in Book II of the Scienza nuova, where we are told how the founders of humanity ‘pictured the sky to themselves as a great animated body, which in that aspect called Jove […] meant to tell them something by the hiss of his bolts and the clap of his thunder.’ In a later section of the same book Vico argues that, with the rise of the power of abstraction, the image of the gods underwent a diminution in the human imagination: ‘Jove becomes so small and light that he is flown about by an eagle.’ (Bergin and Fisch, 118, 128)
VI.C.3.137(j)-(k)

11th EB, ‘Roman Law’ 538: The system as a whole is one of jus as distinguished from fas.

sacer esto
11th EB, ‘Roman Law’ 538: In the royal laws execration (sacratio capitis, sacer esto) was a common sanction; but in the Tables it occurs only once pure and simple, and that with reference to an offence that could be committed only by a patrician,—material loss caused by a patron to his client (patronus, si clienti fraudem faxsit, sacer esto).
VI.C.3.138(c)

marchstone
11th EB, ‘Roman Law’ 528: By fas was understood the will of the gods, the laws given by heaven for men on earth, [...] embodying rules of conduct.[...] It punished [...] the displacement of a boundary or a landmark, not so much because the act was provocative of feud, as because the march-stone itself, as the guarantee of peaceful neighbourhood, was under the guardianship of the gods.

list.item:
filiusfamilias
11th EB, ‘Roman Law’ 530: It might happen that a marriage was fruitless, or that a man saw all his sons go to the grave before him, and that the paterfamilias had thus to face the prospect of the extinction of his family and of his own descent to the tomb without posterity to make him blessed. To obviate so dire a misfortune, he resorted to the practice of adoption, so common in India and Greece. If it was a paterfamilias that he adopted, the process was called adrogation (adrogatio); if it was a filiusfamilias it was simply adoptio.
VI.C.3.138(f)

note.p: 11th EB, ‘Roman Law’ 531: Coemptio was [...] a sale of the woman to the man per aes et libram for a nominal price.[...] Students of comparative law have observed that in coemptio there are clear traces of earlier bride purchase, so common even nowadays among uncivilized tribes, where a real price in cattle or sheep, and not a mere nominal one, has to be paid for the bride.

Irish Statesman 8 March 1924-813
2 Making Hay Without Sunshine
To the Editor of the Irish Statesman Dear Sir,—In connection with the articles which recently appeared in the Statesman emphasising the need of applying scientific methods to agriculture, the following novel method of hay-saving may be of interest to some of your readers.[…] A new method, based on the extermination of the bacteria by passing an electric current, instead of by fermentation, has recently been successfully applied by Mr. Schweiner, of Germany. The freshly-cut meadow hay is first passed through a chaff-cutter placed conveniently at the top of the fodder silos […] The floor is provided with a galvanized iron electrode.

Shaun Esq
Note: In older editions of Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire the author is given as ‘Edward Gibbon, Esq.’
VI.C.3.139(b)

darkness of † death
VI.C.3.139(c)

not mentioned
Gibbon. Decline and Fall, II, 219 (Chapter XV): Under the reign of Tiberius, the whole earth, or at least a celebrated province of the Roman empire, was involved in a preternatural darkness of three hours. Even this miraculous event, which ought to have excited the wonder, the curiosity, and the devotion of mankind, passed without notice in an age of science and history. It happened during the lifetime of Seneca and the elder Pliny, who must have experienced the immediate effects, or received the earliest intelligence of the prodigy. Each of these philosophers, in a laborious work, has recorded all the great phenomena of Nature, earthquakes, meteors, comets, and eclipses, which his indefatiguable curiosity could collect. Both the one and the other have omitted to mention the greatest phenomenon to which the mortal eye has been witness since the creation of the globe.
VI.C.3.139(c)

note.p: Gibbon. Decline and Fall, II, 222n (Chapter XVI): In Cyrene they [the Jews] massacred 220,000 Greeks; in Cypress 240,000; in Egypt a very great multitude. Many of these unhappy victims were sawn asunder, according to a precedent to which David had given the sanction of his example. The victorious Jews devoured the flesh, licked up the blood, and twisted the entrails like a girdle round their bodies. See Dion Cassius, l. lxviii. [c. 32] p. 11145.

The former were the friends, the latter were the enemies, of human kind

Decline and Fall, II, 238n (Chapter XVI): [That St. Jude the Apostle was the brother of Jesus Christ] was at first understood in the most obvious sense, and it was supposed that the brothers of Jesus were the lawful issue of Joseph and Mary. A devout respect for the virginity of the mother of God suggested to the Gnostics, and afterwards to the orthodox Greeks, the expedient of bestowing a second wife on Joseph.

Note: Residuary devise. In law, a gift by will of freehold property is called a devise; a gift by will of personal property is called a bequest. The residuary devise or bequest comprises freehold or personal property not specifically devised or bequested by the testator’s will.

CE ‘Abel’ 36a: [St. Augustine:] “Cain founded a city on earth; but Abel as a stranger and pilgrim looked forward to the city of the saints which is in heaven” (De Civ. Dei, XV, i).
Note: E is Joyce’s abbreviation for Earth.
VI.C.3.146(a)

Abelites, marry — f v adopt
foster
CE ‘Abel’ 36a: The Abelians, or Abelites, a sect in northern Africa mentioned by St. Augustine [...] pretended that they imitated Abel by marrying, yet condemned the use of marriage. They adopted children who also married and lived in the same manner as their foster-parents.
VI.C.3.146(b)

r b naturalr
n artificial
CE ‘Abel’ 36a: [Josephus:] “God was more delighted with [...] (Abel’s) oblation, when He was honoured with what grew naturally of its own accord, than He was with what was the invention of a covetous man, and gotten by forcing the ground.”
MS 47482b-8, MT: Just by nature & natural by design | JJA 57:017 | Apr 1924 | III§1A.*0
1D.*0
2A.*0
2C.*0 | FW 472.10-11

raven, young safe
pray for rain,
food
CE ‘Abel’ 36a: The Koran (Sura v, 30, etc.) agrees with the Bible in the main facts about the sacrifices and murder, but adds the legend that God sent a raven which by scratching in the earth showed Cain how to bury his brother. According to Jewish tradition, Adam and Eve were taught by the raven how to bury their son, and God rewarded the raven by granting three things: (1) his young were to be inviolable, (2) abundance of food, (3) his prayer for rain should be granted

sacrifice
aid for dying
CE ‘Abel’ 36c: In the canon of the Mass his sacrifice is mentioned with those of Melchisedech and Abraham, and his name is placed at the head of the list of saints invoked to aid the dying.

note.p: CE ‘Abel’ 36a: The descendants of Cain were wicked, but, as nothing is said about those of Abel, it is supposed that he had none; or at least that no son was alive at the birth of Seth, “whom God has given me for Abel”, as Eve expressed it (Genesis 4:25).

CE ‘Abel’ 35d: Cheyne holds that “a right view of the story favours the meaning shepherd, or more generally herdsman”; Assyrian ibilu (Ency. Bib., s.v.) “ram, camel, ass, or wild sheep.”
VI.C.3.147(a)

παλεος ήμερον
Page: 155
Check – proper symbols needed here!
Antiquus Dierum
CE ‘Ancient of Days’ 463c: A name given to God by the Prophet Daniel (7:9, 7:13, 7:22), in which he contrasts His eternal powers with the frail existence of the empires of the world. It is from these descriptions of the Almighty that Christian art derived its general manner of representing the first person of the Holy Trinity. Ancient of Days is expressed in Aramaic by Atiq yomin; in the Greek Septuagint by palaios hemeron; and in the Vulgate by Antiquus dierum.
Note: See 128(m).

dead cf b
Note: The habits of earwigs were much discussed in the popular British press during the summer of 1923, when parts of England suffered from what was described as an earwig plague. Under the heading ‘Earwig Trapping’ an article in the Daily Mail 3 Aug-5
4 described in detail the habits of the forficular natives of Becontree, Essex: ‘The Becontree earwig […] is much more fierce and ingenious than the ordinary earwig of commerce […] After a raid they bring up their ambulance corps and carry off their dead for burial in the garden.’ See also VI.A.040.

the Leap
Note: The name of Leixlip on the Liffey is Danish in origin, deriving from Lax-hlaup, meaning salmon leap. The name was further translated into Latin as Saltus Salmonis, and this in turn gave its name to the Baronies of North and South Salt in Co. Kildare.

Note: Celbridge. Village on the Liffey, four miles from Lucan.
VI.C.3.150(h)

New Bridge - John Le Decer
Note: Newbridge. Bridge on the Liffey, near Leixlip. It was built by John le Decer, provost of Dublin in 1308. Paradoxically, it is probably the oldest bridge in Ireland.
VI.C.3.150(i)

Note: Saint Senan (488—560). Bishop and confessor. Thomas Moore has a lyric called ‘Saint Senanus and the Lady’.

Note: Queen Isabella of Castile (1451-1504) gave moral support to her troops by vowing not to change her underwear until after a siege was over, only to have it drag on for months. In consequence isabella or isabelline is a grayish yellow colour. According to another story the queen only had two baths during her lifetime, one at birth and before her marriage.

the devil to pay
(to pitch cover ship
plank)
Note: A line connects ‘devil’ and ‘plank’.
Irish Independent 13 March 1924-6
5 On some Popular Phrases
Nautical Origins Expressions in everyday speech, such as “Making headway,” “Making up leeway,” “Three sheets in the wind,” and many others, are easily recognised as having a nautical origin, but there are other sea-faring terms used just as frequently, such as “To the bitter end,” “The devil to pay,” “To be taken aback,” “To give way,” which lack the salty flavour, and whose origins are more obscure in consequence. To the Bitter End. There is no acridity in the expression, “To the bitter end.” Every ship of the present day has twin pillars of iron called “Bitts,” fixed in convenient places round the deck for mooring the vessel. Some years ago, the end of the anchor cable used to be fastened to one of these bitts in the bow.
When the vessel is anchored, the more cable she has out, the less chance she has of dragging her anchor. But if the weather gets very bad she may have to pay out all her cable, “to the bitter end,” when she can veer no more. The Devil to Pay. Again, the term “the devil to pay,” does not mean paying tribute to the chief of the fallen angels.
“To pay,” in this sense means to cover with pitch the seam between the planks of a wooden ship after it has been previously filled with oakum. The devil refers to the most awkward seam in the vessel, hence its name, and if the devil is not payed, the most difficult part of the work yet remains to be done. Three Sheets in the Wind. Even some of our modern sailors would not find it an easy matter to explain the origin of the expression, “three sheets in the wind,” as used nowadays in describing a drunken man when he has reached the staggering stage.
In a three-masted sailing ship the three largest sails are fastened on the lee side (which is the most sheltered side from the wind) by ropes called sheets. Should however, the wind unexpectedly shift round so that the side on which the sheets are made fast becomes the weather, or windy side, then these sheets are “in the wind,” and the vessel staggers and yaws about in a manner rather reminiscent of a person intoxicated.
Such a shift of wind would, of course be unexpected, and would take the ship “aback,” that is, put the wind on the wrong side of the sails.
VI.C.3.152(k)

The Leader 15 March 1924-133
1: Ireland Re-Visited […] I think it better not to begin with a list of the things on which I don’t agree with “Avis” […] His article on “Boarding-House Bourbons” had my approbation. It interested me also for a peculiar reason.[…] He referred, among other things, to the manner in which the old Ascendancy use the pronoun “they” in referring to the Irish people. Over two years ago I had written about this very same thing for the American press.[…] It will be remembered that if there were ever a time in history when the Irish people were united on a political issue, it was when they determined to resist Conscription in 1918. All sections of Irish Nationalists were represented at the Mansion House Conference. The delegates went from that Conference to Maynooth and got the approbation of the united Hierarchy. 1-2: As Others See Us […] Dear Bob,
Wot ho, old top! S’ donkey’s years since I’ve had a yap with you old man, but Gawd’s trewth the beastly flu got a downer on me and I haven’t felt equal to sendin’ you a line for weeks past. note.p:
Freeman’s Journal 14 March 1924-5
6 Officer Hanged
Lieut. Gaffney Makes Confession
Kerry Crime
Full Responsibility Admitted Ex-Lieut. Jeremiah Gaffney was hanged at 8 o’clock yesterday morning at Mountjoy Gaol for the murder of Thomas Brosnan at Scartaglin, Co. Kerry, on December 6 last.[…] Resigned to Fate The story told of Lieut. Gaffney was that he was quite resigned to the fate he was to meet. […] At no time did he show any sign of fear, and as a warder remarked before the inquest, “he died a splendid and a courageous death.”
On Wednesday he was visited by his father, to whom he spoke quite cheery words, assuring him that all was well with him; he was quite prepared to die, and felt sure of heaven.
“I wish to God,” he told his father, “that everyone was as sure of heaven as I am. Tell mother that, and all my friends, too.”
He bid good-bye to the prison officials before going to the scaffold, where he was attended to the last by the clergymen already referred to.
For some time before that hour a small crowd of people congregated and held watch outside the prison gates.
Most of them were women of the humble class, but so far as could be ascertained, no relatives of Gaffney were present. Women in Tears The women took their stand on the footpath a few yards from the gaol entrance, which they eyed eagerly as they told their beads, reciting aloud the decades of the Rosary.
Nearing the fatal hour the door of the prison opened to admit a warder.[…]
A group of sympathisers dropped to their knees, and four or five of the women commenced to wail.
